title: Trump Rally in Michigan Dominated by More False Statements
description: Former President Donald J. Trump held a rally on Thursday in the key battleground state of Michigan that was notable mainly for his continued false statements and exaggerations on a number of subjects as varied as the 2020 election and the federal government’s response to Hurricane Helene.

title: Acrobat Displays
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues

title: Time-Traveling Film ‘Safety Not Guaranteed’ Hits Some Bumps Onstage
description: From all appearances, Kenneth Calloway is the kind of oddball you would want to steer well clear of. Wild-eyed and radiating a frenetic intensity, he wears a fleece-lined baby-blue earflap hat so oversize that he can’t help looking tiny underneath. Also, there is the matter of the classified newspaper ad he placed.

title: Liz Cheney Endorses Kamala Harris
description: The former congresswoman and Republican exile campaigned with the vice president in the battleground state of Wisconsin.

title: Some Evidence in Adams Case Involves Classified Material, U.S. Says
description: The federal prosecutors who indicted Mayor Eric Adams on corruption charges last week told a judge on Thursday that at least part of their case against him involved classified material that might damage national security if disclosed.

title: Quote of the Day: Brazil’s ‘Elegant’ Idea Could Save Tropical Forests and Generate Returns
description: “Everybody’s saying, look, in principle, this is crazy. But it’s crazy in a kind of interesting way.”

title: For Companies in China, Pulling Out of Xinjiang Poses ‘Messy Dilemma’
description: An investigation by China of an American clothing retailer has escalated concerns among foreign companies about their dependence on Chinese supply chains and the future of their operations in the country.

title: 13 Days After Meeting, She Proposed on TV and He Followed Suit
description: Tessa Enzy Tookes always knew she would end up on TV. In fact, her high school classmates at Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, Conn., voted her “Most Likely to Be on a Reality Show.”

title: Risking a Friendship on the Dance Floor
description: On Feb. 16, 2019, Emil Ari Weinstein had a good feeling. He had just seen “Daddy,” a new play by Jeremy O. Harris, and was on his way to a dance party hosted by Papi Juice, an art collective in New York that celebrates queer and trans people of color. The performance of the play had gone well and the party was lively, but Mr. Weinstein couldn’t stop thinking about his friend, Dr. Alix Esther Masters, who was there with him.

title: They Met For the First Time Twice
description: Devin Ellise Miller recalled first meeting Rieanna Katherine Stewart at a bar in Detroit in February 2022. But Ms. Stewart remembers it differently.

title: A Welcome Break on ‘One of the Hardest Days’ of Her Life
description: On a flight back to New York City from Germany in August 2021, Jonathan-Bruce James King messaged a Tinder match, Mary Kathryn Ann Burke, to ask her out, thinking they could meet sometime in the following week or two.

title: We Were Just Voices in a Dark Room
description: I once moved 800 miles to a city where I had no job and didn’t know anyone besides my fiancé, a man with whom I had spent less than three weeks in person.

title: A More Working-Class British Cabinet, Still Seen as Out of Touch
description: Hot water was a luxury in the home where Angela Rayner, Britain’s deputy prime minister, was raised. Wes Streeting, the health secretary, was born to a single mother who pawned her jewelry to make ends meet. Racist skinheads shouted abuse at the young David Lammy, a Black Briton who is now foreign secretary, near his home in a deprived part of north London.

title: A Rest, a Reset and a Thanks for the Banter
description: Nearly eight years ago, as I opened a new Australia bureau for The New York Times, I tried to imagine what a weekly newsletter from and about the country would aim to do: add some insight and perspective to email inboxes; connect with new readers in a conversational tone; guide people to New York Times coverage they might have overlooked.

title: Friday Briefing: Israel Targets Hezbollah’s Remaining Leaders
description: Israel said it bombed an underground bunker where senior Hezbollah officials were meeting at midnight local time. The targets included Hashem Safieddine, the presumed successor to Hassan Nasrallah, the group’s recently assassinated leader, Israeli officials said. Here’s what we know about Safieddine.

title: Brazil’s Largest Mafia Is Entering Politics. The Government Must Act.
description: The city of São Paulo, Brazil, is about to elect its next mayor, but the talk of the town is about a party that’s not on the ballot on Sunday: The “party of crime,” or as it’s formally known, the First Capital Command (P.C.C.).

title: The Year American Jews Woke Up
description: American Jews were aware, before the pogrom of Oct. 7, 2023, that antisemitism was once again a problem in our collective life.

title: Word of the Day: longitudinal
description: The word longitudinal has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 15 in “Workplace Wellness Programs Have Little Benefit, Study Finds” by Ellen Barry:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Chasing Down a Trail of Climate Conspiracies
description: A few months ago, I came across a headline that didn’t seem to make sense: Republican lawmakers in Tennessee voted to ban solar geoengineering, a largely theoretical method of artificially cooling the Earth.

title: Their Uber Driver Crashed. A Pizza Order Unraveled Their Injury Lawsuit.
description: A New Jersey couple was heading home from dinner in an Uber in March 2022 when their driver T-boned another car, leaving them with serious injuries, including spine and rib fractures.

title: Woman With Flowers
description: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

title: Why Eric Adams Is Nothing Like David Dinkins
description: In the weeks before he was indicted in a federal corruption investigation, Eric Adams, New York City’s second Black mayor, began regularly comparing himself to David Dinkins, the city’s first Black mayor — a pairing so misaligned it could put you in mind of Donald Trump likening himself to someone like Jimmy Carter. The apparent point was to warn New Yorkers that if they did not back his bid for re-election, the city would reprise its racist past, denying another Black mayor a second term. Mr. Dinkins lost his re-election effort to a race-baiting Rudy Giuliani, while the most serious threats to an Adams win — beyond a criminal prosecution — are coming from the progressive left and include candidates like Zellnor Myrie, a Black state senator with immigrant parents.

title: Late Night Heaps Scorn on Trump’s Latest Defense
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Four Weeks To Go: “The Daily” Politics Roundtable
description: With Kamala Harris and Donald Trump locked in the tightest of races, who will come out on top? Listen to our political round table on the 2024 election.

title: A Near Exact Tie in the Polls
description: After an eventful week for the presidential race, the candidates are even in the polls. The Times journalists Nate Cohn, Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher discuss the state of the race, with the Nov. 5 election nearly a month away.

title: We Want to Know Your Questions About Theater, Film, Music and Culture
description: When you work on arts and entertainment coverage, and part of the job is keeping up with what’s on TV, or Broadway, or at the Met (both the museum and the opera house), people in your life invariably have questions: What should I watch? What should I read? What do I need to see while I’m in town?

title: A Compact Weekend House Filled With Comfort
description: Aya Maceda and Kurt Arnold really didn’t want a second home in the country — or so they thought. But that was before the pandemic coaxed them into sampling rural life in upstate New York.

title: These Are Boom Times for ‘Degrowth’
description: There’s long been one mantra in mainstream economics: Growth is good.

title: Just How Much Control Can an Artist Have Over Their Work?
description: “WHAT AM I looking at?”

title: Once More Unto the Breach: A New Take on Henry V Showcases His Contradictions
description: Why read a new, 400-page biography of England’s King Henry V? Because, writes the best-selling historian and television journalist Dan Jones, while Henry ruled for less than a decade, “his reign is a case study in the art of leadership in a time of crisis, which feels especially apposite as I write these words today.”

title: The War’s Toll on Sick Ukrainian Children
description: Sonya, a young Ukrainian girl, was being treated for eye cancer. Then Russia invaded Ukraine. Lynsey Addario, a photographer on assignment for The New York Times who has covered every major war and humanitarian crisis of her generation, tells Sonya’s story.

title: Too Scared to Watch Horror Movies? These 5 Tips May Help.
description: The October ritual of watching horror movies in the lead-up to Halloween can be exhilarating. Unless, of course, you can’t quite stomach the gory and gruesome, or even the spooky and spine-tingling.

title: 5 Picture Books About Space, From the Sublime to the Silly
description: These are lines from a poem by Ada Limón that has been engraved on Europa Clipper, the space probe NASA will launch on Oct. 10, if all goes well. (One suspects the two American astronauts now enjoying an unplanned stay on the International Space Station will not be holding their breaths.) Limón, the United States poet laureate since 2022, may give humanity too much credit when it comes to our capacity for constant awe, but I suppose positive thinking is part of the job description when you are commissioned to write a poem that will drift around the cosmos for eons and could serve as our calling card. Anne Sexton might be a little dark for impressionable ETs.

title: How John Lewis Became a Moral Force in America
description: John Lewis was enrolled in a seminary in the Jim Crow city of Nashville when he embraced the belief that allowing himself to be beaten nearly to death in public would hasten the collapse of Southern apartheid.

title: As America’s Marijuana Use Grows, So Do the Harms
description: In midcoast Maine, a pediatrician sees teenagers so dependent on cannabis that they consume it practically all day, every day — “a remarkably scary amount,” she said.

title: Kamala Harris Is Doing Something Brilliant Up There on the Tightrope
description: Given that Kamala Harris is running for the world’s most powerful elected office, it’s no surprise to see voters and pundits commenting on her “power moves” and “boss energy.” What’s remarkable is that they mean it as a compliment. That’s a far cry from the experience of many women — in politics and beyond — who have dared to assert themselves.

title: She Was Having Bouts of Vision Loss. Why?
description: The 22-year-old woman gripped the thick, battered notebook on her lap. It contained her medical records dating back to when she first got sick 18 years earlier. Her parents had always been the ones to bring the notebook to her medical visits. But she had just moved to New York City to go to nursing school, and this was the first time she was seeing a doctor without them. She had an appointment to meet a new physician at the N.Y.U. Langone Multiple Sclerosis Comprehensive Care Center with the hope that he would help her manage the illness she’d been dealing with for as long as she could remember. And maybe even figure out a mystery that none of the many doctors she’d seen had been able to solve: What exactly was wrong with her?

title: The Supreme Court Should Stop the Glossip Execution
description: Nearly 90 years ago, in a case involving prosecutorial misconduct, the Supreme Court laid down its view of a prosecutor’s duty, one that has been widely repeated in court decisions ever since. The prosecution’s interest in a criminal prosecution, the court wrote succinctly, “is not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be done.”

title: Bucking Trends, an Opera Company in Atlanta Is Growing
description: Walking through a repurposed industrial space in Atlanta one recent afternoon, Tomer Zvulun gestured toward a cafe table in the middle of a wraparound stage covered in graffiti.

title: In ‘La Máquina,’ Gael García Bernal and Diego Luna Get a Rematch
description: Sitting cross-legged on the floor at the Château Marmont in Los Angeles, Gael García Bernal stared with admiration at his lifelong friend and fellow actor Diego Luna. Just the night before, they had walked onstage at the Peacock Theater and, as expected, presented the Emmy for best director of a limited or anthology series or TV movie.

title: Farm to Table to Screen: A Close Look at How America Feeds Itself
description: In the early days of the pandemic, I accidentally ordered five chickens and three dozen giant, fragrant Amalfi Coast lemons. I thought I’d ordered one five-pound chicken and three lemons from a local restaurant supplier who’d had to quickly pivot to home cooks like me. But between my frazzled, stressed brain and their usual order quantities, wires got crossed.

title: DNA Reveals the Origin Stories of America’s Captive Tigers
description: In 2020, the Netflix documentary series “Tiger King” introduced the world to America’s large population of captive tigers. Estimates by experts suggest there may be as many as 7,000 of the big cats in the United States today, while only around 5,500 tigers survive in the wild in other countries.

title: $650,000 Homes in Nova Scotia
description: This two-unit 1979 home, with a total of seven bedrooms and three baths, is in the community of Barton and sits on a knoll overlooking St. Mary’s Bay, which eventually empties into the Bay of Fundy off Nova Scotia’s west coast. The town of Digby, with a population of about 2,000, is 10 miles east on Annapolis Basin, also off the Bay of Fundy, and offers shopping and dining particularly themed around Digby scallops, for which the town is known. Whale watching is the other popular tourism activity here.

title: A Death in Childbirth Raises New Questions About a Hospital
description: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll explore deepening concerns over maternal health care at a Brooklyn hospital where three women have died during childbirth since 2020. We’ll also look at a hearing in the case of Daniel Penny, who choked Jordan Neely to death in a subway last year.

title: Where to Drink Wine in Montreal
description: Montreal is one of the best cities in North America to drink wine. Great lists are plentiful and relatively inexpensive, particularly for Americans who will benefit from a favorable exchange rate. And invariably, in many of the best wine bars and restaurants, the wine is natural.

title: Kamala Harris and the Influence of an Estranged Father Just Two Miles Away
description: Kamala Harris recalled a childhood memory of her father in her convention speech two months ago, when she said he exhorted her in an unnamed park to “Run, Kamala, run. Don’t be afraid. Don’t let anything stop you.”

title: Is Nighttime Depression Really a Thing?
description: It’s not uncommon for our minds to unleash a torrent of difficult feelings under the cover of darkness: sadness and negative thoughts may surface at night, making sleep hard to come by.

title: The House That Malin+Goetz Built (And Built Again)
description: Follow the journey of Matthew Malin and Andrew Goetz as they recreate their dream house destroyed by fire.

title: Pandemic Start-Ups Are Thriving, and Helping to Fuel the Economy
description: Hector Xu was on track for a career in academia when the pandemic upended his plans.

title: The World’s Oldest Termite Mound Is 34,000 Years and Counting
description: Last month, Michele Francis, an environmental scientist at Stellenbosch University in South Africa, relocated to central Connecticut only to discover that her new home showed signs of termite damage. When an exterminator suggested setting out traps, Dr. Francis demurred. “I wondered if I could persuade the termites to eat the trees around my house rather than the house itself,” she said. “I hold termites in high esteem.”

title: Unpacking the Role JD Vance Played on That Debate Stage
description: This week the hosts discuss what was obscured by the civility of the V.P. debate, and consider what JD Vance and Tim Walz really offer their running mates and their parties’ futures.

title: 5 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Directed by Todd Phillips, this crime-thriller-musical follows Joker (Joaquin Phoenix) as he stands trial for murder and falls for Harley Quinn (Lady Gaga) in Arkham Asylum.

title: What to Know About the 2024 Nobel Prize Winners
description: Every October, committees in Sweden and Norway name laureates in a variety of prizes related to science, literature and economics, as well as peace work. In total, six prizes are awarded.

title: Can California Regulate A.I.? + Silicon Valley’s Super Babies + System Update!
description: On Sunday, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vetoed Senate Bill 1047, an A.I. safety bill that would have curtailed the growth of the technology. What received a lot less attention were the 18 other important A.I. bills he signed into law over the past month. We walk through what is in them and what they mean for the rest of the country. Then, The Information’s Julia Black joins to discuss the baby craze that’s sweeping Silicon Valley, including investment in some wild new fertility technologies. And finally, it’s time for a system update! We get into OpenAI’s massive fund-raising deal and the senator who hopped on a call with a “deepfake” former Ukrainian official.

title: Oliver Sacks Archive Heads to the New York Public Library
description: For his 75th birthday, friends of the writer and neurologist Oliver Sacks gave him a printout of his brain scan inscribed with well wishes. Alongside it was a mock-scientific text describing a newly identified condition: “Brilliant Bi-Hemispheric Cortical Balance syndrome.”

title: The Economy Is at a Hinge Moment
description: We have hit a hinge moment in the economy. For the past few years, there has been one problem on policymakers’ minds: inflation. But in mid-September, the Federal Reserve called an end to that era when it cut interest rates by half a percentage point. Inflation, it was saying, is no longer the problem. It has come down from around 9 percent annually to around 2.5 percent. But unemployment is creeping up again. There are some signs of economic stress. Having spent the past year cooling the economy down, the Fed now feels it’s both safe and necessary to heat it back up, at least a bit.

title: The One Thing Not Named Trump That Trump Cares About
description: The centerpiece of Donald Trump’s second-term domestic agenda is the mass deportation of what he and his campaign say are 20 million or even 25 million undocumented immigrants.

title: ‘It Took Over Everything’: Stories of Marijuana’s Little-Known Risks
description: As marijuana legalization spreads across the country, people are consuming more of the drug, more often and at ever-higher potencies. Most of the tens of millions of people using marijuana, for health benefits or for fun, don’t experience problems. But a growing number, mainly heavy users, have experienced addiction, psychosis and other harmful effects, The New York Times found.

title: What Does College Football Have to Do With College?
description: The black sky emptied as about 50,000 rain-soaked University of Colorado football fans exhaled in improbable joy at Folsom Field. This was after the Hail Mary pass caught as time expired, after the game-clinching fumble that squirted out of the end zone in overtime.

title: Researchers Find Cannibalized Victim of 19th-Century Arctic Voyage
description: Into the frozen fray they went, the explorer Sir John Franklin and his crew of 128 men, sailing from England in 1845 in search of the Northwest Passage. And there, in the unforgiving expanse of the Canadian Arctic, they perished. No one knows exactly what happened.

title: Democrats Have a Corruption Problem. They Can’t Keep Ignoring It.
description: For the past eight years and across two impeachment trials, the Democratic Party has defined itself in opposition to Donald Trump’s corruption, assailing the ways he abused the presidency for his own financial and political benefit. But with Mayor Eric Adams of New York fighting a federal corruption indictment, former Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey awaiting sentencing for a similar fraud and bribery scheme and numerous California officials sitting in federal prison, it’s hard to deny that corruption is a bipartisan problem.

title: Is Katy Perry’s ‘143’ Really That Bad?
description: Katy Perry released her seventh studio album, ”143,” last week to nearly universal critical disdain. But the magnitude and gleeful nature of the vitriol were not caused by her bland new music alone.On today’s episode of “The Culture Desk,” Melissa Kirsch, deputy editor of culture and lifestyle, talks with the pop music critic Lindsay Zoladz about why the reaction to “143” has been especially intense in this current cultural moment.

title: How to Stage a Viral Fashion Show
description: On the final night of Paris Fashion Week, everyone went to Disneyland.

title: 4 Ways to Turn Around a Bad Day
description: When I hit midlife, I discovered that you can pull a muscle in all kinds of new ways: sneezing, parking a car. And, as I found out last week, you can tweak your back just getting out of bed.

title: Every Election Has Big Swings, Even in a Polarized Country. This One Will Too.
description: In today’s polarized era, it’s easy to assume that nothing ever matters in American politics — that every four years, the same election happens over and over, with the same demographic groups lining up behind the same candidates in the same states.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 4, 2024
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the sequel “Joker: Folie à Deux.”

title: Obama, Democrats’ Elder Statesman, Will Stump for Harris in Final Election Push
description: Former President Barack Obama, the popular elder statesman of the Democratic Party, will stump for Vice President Kamala Harris in battleground states in the month before Election Day, beginning with a campaign stop next Thursday in Pittsburgh.

title: The Bold. The Beautiful. The Fat Bear.
description: Voters have a lot to weigh: leadership qualities, policy agenda, experience. But over the past decade, one race has been defined by the amount of wild salmon that can be smashed into a mouth.

title: ‘Mom, I Want to Live’: A Young Girl Battles War and Cancer
description: Splayed out on a pink bedspread, wearing a pink tank top and surrounded by stuffed pink unicorns, 6-year-old Sonya Liakh unscrewed the port to the catheter in her chest. She took a pre-filled syringe of morphine from the tray held by the nurse beside her, deftly inserted the syringe into her port, and pushed the contents into her jugular vein.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,204
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 482
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Four Weeks to Go
description: With Election Day fast approaching, polls show the race between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump to be the closest in a generation.

title: Oil Prices Rise on Biden’s Offhand Remarks, and U.S. Ports Reopen
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Europe Raises Tariffs on China’s E.V.s, Confronting a Key Trade Partner
description: The European Union voted on Friday to impose higher tariffs on electric vehicles imported from China, risking tensions with an important trading partner in an effort to protect an industry crucial to Europe’s economy.

title: Labor Market Shows Unexpected Strength
description: Many have doubted it. Even the optimists have worried about it. But despite the hand-wringing, the American economy appears to be in remarkably good shape.

title: A Crackdown
description: For much of the Biden administration’s first three years in office, migration surged at the Mexican border. Administration officials frequently argued that the problem was beyond their control — a reflection not of U.S. policy but of global forces pushing people toward the border.

title: FIFA Limits on Player Transfers Are Illegal, Europe’s Top Court Rules
description: Europe’s top court ruled on Friday that some elements of soccer’s multibillion-dollar global player trading market are illegal, a decision that is likely to force changes to the way thousands of athletes move between teams around the world every year.

title: Israel Expands Evacuation Warnings in Southern Lebanon After Renewed Strikes
description: Israel appeared to expand its military operations in Lebanon on Friday, issuing new evacuation warnings across the south and bombing a border crossing with Syria, hours after a series of airstrikes shook the outskirts of the Lebanese capital, Beirut.

title: Would You Want to Be a Child Star?
description: Have you ever dreamed of being a child star?

title: Exploring Your Political Identity and Values: A How-To Guide for Our 2024 Coming of Age Contest
description: What can you show or tell us to help explain what it’s like to grow up in this political moment?

title: Jobs and Oil Prices Are Keeping Markets on Edge
description: With just over a month to go until Election Day, Friday’s jobs report, set to be published at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, has outsize importance. Investors will look for clues to what the Fed might do next with interest rates, as well as how the economy is doing.

title: Britain Backs Plan to Store Carbon Dioxide Under the Sea
description: The British government said Friday that it would back two large proposals to capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial plants and bury the gas beneath the sea.

title: At Least 16 Die as Floods Sweep Through Bosnia
description: A night of heavy rainfall left at least 16 people dead and large parts of southern Bosnia under water or smothered by landslides, the authorities said on Friday.

title: In a Rare Sermon, Iran’s Supreme Leader Praises Oct. 7 Attacks as ‘Logical’ and Warns Israel
description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, led Friday prayers for the first time in almost five years, delivering a sermon during a memorial service in Tehran for Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in which he railed against Israel and warned of further retaliation, if necessary, for its actions.

title: How States Are Enticing Employers to Help Their Workers Save for College
description: As higher education becomes ever more expensive, some states are giving employers incentives to contribute to 529 college savings accounts for their workers.

title: Meta Unveils Instant A.I. Video Generator That Adds Sounds
description: In February, the artificial intelligence start-up OpenAI unveiled technology called Sora that let people generate photorealistic videos — like woolly mammoths trotting through a snowy meadow — simply by typing a sentence into a box on a computer screen.

title: The Jobs Report Is Good News for the Fed
description: Federal Reserve officials have been watching the job market closely, wary that it might be cracking under the pressure of high interest rates. The September employment report does a lot to alleviate those concerns.

title: Gender Identity Changes Must Be Recognized Across E.U. Borders, Court Rules
description: The European Union’s top court on Friday said governments in the bloc must recognize legal changes to a person’s gender identity and name made in other E.U. nations, a milestone ruling that rights campaigners say will give transgender people more freedom to live and work around the region.

title: China Buys Nearly All of Iran’s Oil Exports, but Has Options if Israel Attacks
description: Iran’s oil infrastructure has been pushed to the center of the escalating conflict in the Middle East, but an Israeli strike on Iran’s energy facilities would also affect China directly.

title: Scientists Found a Surprising Way to Make Fungus Happy
description: The soil beneath our feet, home to fungi, bacteria, beetles and worms, may not seem like the most jazzy environment. But if you stuck a powerful enough microphone in the soil, you’d be surprised at how hopping it is, acoustically speaking. That has led some microbiologists to wonder: Are there sounds that actually encourage microorganisms to grow? And could serenading a fungus make it twist and shout?

title: Saoirse Ronan Has Lived, and Acted, Through a Lot
description: “I wish I could live through something,” says the teenage title character in the 2017 movie “Lady Bird,” yearning for a life beyond suburban Sacramento.

title: In Georgia, Black Men’s Frustration With Democrats Creates Opening for Trump
description: Over the last month, Freddie Hicks, 23, has received dozens of Republican mailers addressed to him at his home in deep-blue DeKalb County, an Atlanta suburb.

title: The Job Market Is Chugging Along, Completing a Solid Economic Picture
description: For months, the economy has been like a jigsaw with one mismatched piece: Consumer spending has been holding up and overall growth has been solid, but the job market has looked treacherously wobbly.

title: Jobs Report Adds to Economic Momentum for Harris
description: Vice President Kamala Harris probably could not have hoped for a better run of pre-election economic data than what the United States has enjoyed over the last month.

title: Supreme Court to Decide Whether Mexico Can Sue U.S. Gun Makers
description: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Mexico may sue gun manufacturers in the United States for aiding in the trafficking of weapons used by drug cartels.

title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: “Born to Fly,” a flashy, adrenaline-pumping film from the Chinese director Liu Xiaoshi, has a lot in common with “Top Gun.” Like Tom Cruise’s Maverick, Lei Yu (Wang Yibo) is a cocky fighter pilot with big potential. Yu is sent to a flight school for exceptional test pilots, who fly next-generation planes to their breaking points. The academy then gathers data from the extreme flights to train combat fliers. Yu, again with echoes of Maverick, starts out declaring, “No one knows the limits better than I do,” before becoming a team player.

title: 5 New Horror Movies to Stream for Halloween
description: A mother braves the elements, and evil, in this busy but hackneyed feature debut from the directors Karrie Crouse and Will Joines.

title: Orange Beef Will Cure What Ails You
description: Good morning. The way things usually work for me this time of year: Weekdays are beautiful, crisp and clear. Guides I know text me at work with shots of beautiful fish caught by their grateful clients.

title: Adapting to the Champions League’s New Reality
description: Lille’s players lingered on the field at the Stade Pierre-Mauroy, communing with their fans. The stands were still full, long after the game had finished, and the party was showing no signs of ending. Ethan Mbappé — famous name, if not quite a familiar face — wore the broad grin of a man who was going to take considerable pleasure in messaging his brother later.

title: Arts District, Decades in the Making, in Ruins After Helene
description: The French Broad River provided a scenic backdrop as an industrial neighborhood in Asheville transformed over the past 40 years into the River Arts District, a vibrant creative hub for art studios and galleries.

title: At Least 70 People Dead in Gang Attack in Haiti
description: The gang members, armed with automatic weapons, stormed into the small town of Pont-Sondé in central Haiti at around 3 a.m. on Thursday.

title: Extreme Weather Gives Video Games a Powerful Adversary
description: The storms start off small in the vehicular survival game Pacific Drive. Raindrops fall on the windshield, as lightning cracks ominously in the distance. In a few minutes, the pristine Olympic Peninsula will shake with nature’s full terrible force.

title: Engaging With a Conservative on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Undecided Voters Tell Us About Their Biggest Worries
description: Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris are starkly different presidential candidates. So why are so many voters —  roughly 1 in 6 — still unsure of their choice?

title: What Game Theory Tells Us About the Threat of an Israel-Iran War
description: For years, the conflict between Israel and Iran had unofficial but fairly clear rules, allowing the enemies to maintain an uneasy equilibrium in the Middle East.

title: 69 Percent of New Yorkers Think Eric Adams Should Resign, Poll Shows
description: Most New York City residents think Mayor Eric Adams broke the law, is doing a bad job as mayor and should resign, according to a poll released Friday, the first since he was indicted last week on bribery and corruption charges.

title: Supreme Court Lets Biden Plans on Mercury and Methane Move Forward
description: The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not stop the Biden administration from enforcing rules to reduce emissions of two pollutants: mercury, a hazardous neurotoxin, and methane, a potent greenhouse gas.

title: Nibi the Beaver’s Future Reached the Courts. Then the Massachusetts Governor Stepped In.
description: This is a story about wildlife, about bureaucracy, about politics, about the internet.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: This week, the hosts focused mostly on the vice-presidential debate but took a moment to discuss recent inflammatory comments by former President Trump.

title: New Los Angeles Police Chief Is a Conventional Choice
description: As Mayor Karen Bass of Los Angeles spent the last few months talking to police officers at daily roll calls, a consistent theme emerged: Morale is so low that rank-and-file officers are unwilling to recruit others to their depleted department.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Tries His Hand at Fashion
description: Mark Zuckerberg would like us all to know that learning is best achieved through suffering.

title: How Does Your Facial Hair Make You Feel?
description: Many women have visible facial hair. It can be a part of our appearances from a young age or can increase as we get older. Sometimes it’s caused by hormone imbalances, but in most cases it’s simply a part of life. But despite its prevalence, some women feel shame around it.

title: 3 Warming Dishes for Crisp Fall Days
description: I remember the first time my mother allowed me to bake by myself: I must’ve been 6 or 7 when I made poppy seed-coated pretzel bagels. Of course, I forgot the salt in the dough, and they ended up a little bland. But I had found my passion.

title: Hamas Leader Is Holding Out for a Bigger War, U.S. Officials Say
description: The leader of Hamas, Yahya Sinwar, has become fatalistic after nearly a year of war in Gaza and is determined to see Israel embroiled in a wider regional conflict, U.S. officials said.

title: Bring Up the Bodies in 4 New Crime Novels
description: Kate Atkinson has been dazzling readers ever since her 1995 debut, “Behind the Scenes at the Museum,” about a spectacularly dysfunctional Yorkshire family. She embraced speculative fiction with “Life After Life,” spy fiction with “Transcription,” historical adventure with “Shrines of Gaiety” and crime fiction with her series featuring the private investigator Jackson Brodie.

title: Capturing a Community in Ruin
description: It was 4 a.m. and my wife and I lay awake as the rain hammered our metal roof. The trees silhouetted against the night sky whipped violently back and forth.

title: Inside a Republican Ad Accusing Jon Tester of Flip-Flopping on Immigration
description: The Republican political action committee American Crossroads has spent just over $2 million on this 30-second television advertisement supporting Tim Sheehy, the Republican candidate for Senate in deep-red Montana who is trying to unseat Senator Jon Tester, the Democratic incumbent. The outcome of the race could determine control of the chamber, and both parties are spending in accordance with the high stakes. American Crossroads began airing this particular spot in late September, according to AdImpact.

title: Severe Rainstorm Floods Parts of Southern Bosnia
description: Heavy rainfall left multiple towns and villages flooded across southern Bosnia.

title: Lauren Mayberry’s Lush Pop Ecstasy, and 13 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: The Savannah Bananas Needed a Bigger Stage
description: Getting tickets to Savannah Bananas games over the last few years has been so difficult that the barnstorming baseball team has drawn comparisons to Taylor Swift. And like Ms. Swift, the Bananas, who have danced their way to national stardom, will be taking their act from intimate venues to almost exclusively giant stadiums in 2025.

title: 10 Unforgettable Kris Kristofferson Covers
description: “You can look at Nashville pre-Kris and post-Kris,” Bob Dylan once said of Kris Kristofferson, who died on Saturday, “because he changed everything.”

title: Disaster Funding Has Its Own Perils
description: When congressional leaders decided not to call lawmakers back from the campaign trail for an emergency session to fund relief and rebuilding efforts after Hurricane Helene, they cited practical considerations.

title: Syria, Russia Remain Silent on Reported Airstrikes Near a Russian Base in Syria
description: Airstrikes hit an ammunition warehouse near a large Russian air base in northern Syria, a Britain-based monitoring group and a Russian military blogger close to Moscow’s defense ministry said on Thursday.

title: As Bird Flu Spreads, Two New Cases Diagnosed in California
description: Two more people were diagnosed with bird flu this week, even as scientists in Missouri continued to investigate a possible cluster of infections in that state, federal health officials said at a news briefing on Friday.

title: Conservative Activists Are Monitoring, and Filming, Voter Registration Sites
description: One sweltering morning in Phoenix, four workers from a Latino nonprofit stood with clipboards outside a motor-vehicle office to do the grunt work of democracy: persuading reluctant Americans to register to vote.

title: Jean Hanff Korelitz on ‘The Sequel’
description: In 2021, the novelist Jean Hanff Korelitz had a hit with “The Plot,” a book that was partly a mystery, partly a thriller and entirely a delicious sendup of the publishing industry. It told the tale of a once-promising writer, Jacob, who steals somebody else’s story idea and reaches undreamed-of levels of success before things go very badly for him.

title: Biden Will Allow Legal Permission to Lapse for Migrants From 4 Countries
description: The Biden administration said Friday it would allow the temporary legal permission for migrants from Cuba, Venezuela, Haiti, and Nicaragua to lapse, forcing hundreds of thousands of people to find other methods to stay in the country or face deportation.

title: I’m a Queer Man Who Had a Fling With Another Guy. Should His Girlfriend Be Told?
description: I’m a man who recently had a fling with a man who is in a monogamous heterosexual relationship. We had sex twice. While I am in a nonmonogamous relationship myself, I respect the practice of monogamy. Normally I wouldn’t get involved with someone who is unfaithful. But here I felt my moral obligations to a struggling member of my own queer community were greater than those to his partner.

title: ‘Megalopolis’ and the Vexations of Decadence
description: “Megalopolis,” the 85-year-old Francis Ford Coppola’s $140 million passion project, is not by any stretch of the imagination a good movie. It’s easy to understand why he had to fund it largely out of his own pocket, notwithstanding his name and reputation. And as with many later Coppola movies, it’s hard to understand how the artist who made “The Godfather,” “The Conversation” and “Apocalypse Now” could also be responsible for some of his newest film’s creative choices.

title: The Dollar Is Too Strong for America’s Own Good
description: The economist Richard Koo built pianos in Hong Kong for his father-in-law for a year and a half between college and graduate school. Now he is the chief economist of Nomura Research Institute in Japan.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 5, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: ‘The Franchise’ Review: Cutting Marvel Down to Size
description: The new HBO series “The Franchise” satirizes the making of a superhero movie by a fictional movie studio that is Marvel in all but name. (The actual fictional name is Maximum Studios.) Warner Bros. Discovery, HBO’s parent, is Marvel’s bitter rival in the superhero field, so you might expect the show to offer an extra measure of savage mockery.

title: Biden Says the Election Will Be Fair. But He’s Not Sure It Will Be Peaceful.
description: President Biden said Friday he was not sure next month’s election would be peaceful if former President Donald J. Trump lost his bid for another term in the White House.

title: Iran’s Foreign Minister Reaches Out to Arab Leaders in Lebanon, Qatar
description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, was in Lebanon on Friday after meetings with leaders of Gulf countries earlier in the week in Qatar, where he and Iran’s President Masoud Pezeshkian endeavored to shore up relations with some of Iran’s closest neighbors.

title: A Pentagon Debate: Are U.S. Deployments Containing the Fighting, or Inflaming It?
description: As the Israeli offensive in Lebanon expands to include ground incursions and intensifying airstrikes, senior Pentagon officials are discussing whether the enhanced U.S. military presence in the region is containing a widening war, as they had hoped, or inflaming it.

title: Trump’s Return to Butler Is Sure to Be a Spectacle. Is It Safe?
description: Five days after being shot by a would-be assassin in Butler, Pa., former President Donald J. Trump stood onstage at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, surrounded by images of his blood-streaked face. “I will tell you exactly what happened, and you’ll never hear it from me a second time,” he said, “because it’s actually too painful to tell.”

title: A Once-Dormant Hurricane Season Is Spinning Into Action
description: There are just under two months left before the official Atlantic hurricane season ends in November, and with millions of people across the Southeast United States still assessing the damage of Hurricane Helene and two more storms churning at sea, experts are warning it isn’t over yet. It may even last into December.

title: For Savannah, It’s Not Just a Port. It’s an Economy.
description: Viewed through a narrow lens, Savannah is a popular tourist destination with a seemingly aesthetic profile, accentuated by its Revolutionary War history, historic Black churches and colorful Victorian homes surrounded by Spanish moss.

title: Harris Ad to Showcase Support of Liz Cheney and Other Republicans
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign will air a new ad in battleground states featuring endorsements from a retired general, former members of the Trump administration and former Representative Liz Cheney.

title: Death Penalty, Nuclear Waste and More: Supreme Court Rounds Out Coming Term
description: The Supreme Court on Friday added more than a dozen cases to the docket for its new term, which begins next week.

title: Trump Takes Aim at Legal Immigration
description: Former President Donald J. Trump, who is seeking re-election on the same hard line against undocumented immigrants that helped carry him to power in 2016, has said he is not opposed to legal immigration into the United States.

title: Joe D. Bryan, 84, Dies; His Murder Conviction Raised Troubling Questions
description: Joe D. Bryan, a former high school principal who was released from prison in Texas after serving 33 years for a murder conviction based on expert testimony that was later discredited, and whose claims of innocence drew intense media scrutiny, died on Sept. 22 at his home in Houston. He was 84.

title: In Key Nevada County, Harassment of Election Workers Takes a Toll
description: Cari-Ann Burgess, the interim registrar of voters for Nevada’s Washoe County, was the third top elections official the county had seen in four years.

title: Ex-OceanGate Employee’s Remarks Hint at Titan Disaster Lawsuits to Come
description: It happened in 2017 at the Scuttlebutt Family Pub down by the docks in Everett, Wash., just steps from where OceanGate was building a new kind of undersea craft. The low-cost submersible was to be so large and strong that it could take five people down miles to see the Titanic up close.

title: Biden Voices Concern That the Election May Not Be ‘Peaceful’
description: President Biden said he was confident next month’s election would be free and fair, but that he was concerned about what former President Donald J. Trump and his supporters would do if he lost his bid for another term.

title: Ports Rush to Reopen After First Major Strike in Decades Is Suspended
description: Hours after a longshoremen’s union on the East and Gulf Coasts agreed to suspend its strike, major ports rushed to reopen on Friday and get cargo to businesses that have spent the last few days racked with fear over lost sales.

title: Trump Falsely Promotes Endorsement From Banker Who Hasn’t Endorsed Him
description: Donald J. Trump announced what would have been groundbreaking news on Wall Street, in a post on his social media website, Truth Social, on Friday afternoon. At 1:56 p.m., Mr. Trump published, alongside a siren emoji, a claim that he’d been endorsed by America’s most influential banker, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon.

title: In Rare Visit to White House Press Briefing, Biden Cautions Israel
description: A day after President Biden said the United States was “in discussion” about the possibility that Israel might strike Iran’s vast oil fields, he suggested that Israel should consider alternative ways to retaliate against Iran.

title: U.S. Conducts Strikes Against Houthis in Yemen
description: The United States Central Command said on Friday that it struck Houthi targets in Yemen, including “Houthi offensive military capabilities,” in an effort to secure international waterways.

title: Entire Chicago Education Board to Resign Amid Tensions Between Mayor and Schools Chief
description: All of Chicago’s board of education members announced their resignations on Friday amid tense disagreements between Mayor Brandon Johnson and the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools over the school district’s budget next year.

title: Yoga to the People Founder Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion
description: The founder and co-owner of Yoga to the People, a wildly successful chain of studios that began in the East Village of Manhattan and later spread to nearly half a dozen states outside New York before closing in 2020, pleaded guilty to federal tax evasion on Friday.

title: The Economy Looks Strong After the Latest Jobs Report
description: The American labor market, which for months has worried even some optimistic economists, looked in remarkably good shape today after the government released a new employment report. Businesses added 254,000 jobs last month, far outpacing expectations. The unemployment rate declined to 4.1 percent and wage growth remained strong.

title: Judge Halts Biden Student Debt Plan Right After It Was Allowed to Proceed
description: A federal judge in Missouri temporarily blocked a Biden administration plan to cancel student debt less than a day after another judge had allowed it to proceed, throwing into uncertainty the fate of a program that could affect more than 27 million borrowers.

title: Richard Mayhew, Painter of Abstract Landscapes, Dies at 100
description: Richard Mayhew, a painter of Black and Native American heritage who was known for his explosively colorful abstract landscapes — he called them “mindscapes” — that traced the emotional contours of nature as well as his forebears’ historical relationship to the land, died on Sept. 26 at his home in Soquel, Calif., on the northern coast. He was 100.

title: Still Searching for Their Loved Ones, a Week After Hurricane Helene
description: The last time Drew McLean’s parents saw him, he was marveling at the power of Tropical Storm Helene as it washed over their home in the mountains of North Carolina.

title: Shock in French Court Shown Videos of Men Accused of Raping Drugged Woman
description: A leaden silence descended upon the courtroom as the videos began to play over three screens.

title: Biden Cautions Israel on Striking Iranian Oil Fields
description: President Biden said Israel should consider alternative ways of retaliating against Iran, a day after he said the United States was “in discussion” about the possibility of Israel striking Iran’s oil fields.

title: Her 8-Year-Old Drove Herself to Target and Became an Internet Star
description: When Tangie Wilson’s 8-year-old daughter, Zoe, asked to use her iPad early one Sunday morning in September at their home in Bedford, Ohio, she assumed her child had settled into her room or on the couch with the device, so she went back to sleep.

title: Trump Campaign Distributes Raised Funds to Victims in Butler, Pa.
description: The Trump campaign said on Friday that it was distributing $6.6 million that others donated to a GoFundMe account that it set up for victims of the July 13 assassination attempt on the former president in Butler, Pa.

title: What to Know About the Verdict in the Tyre Nichols Case
description: Three former Memphis police officers were found guilty on Thursday of federal witness tampering charges in the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man. They were acquitted of the more serious charge of violating his civil rights by causing his death. Emily Cochrane, a New York Times reporter who covers the American South, explains.

title: Reporter Asks Biden if He Would Reconsider Dropping Out of the Race
description: He was almost out the door.

title: It’s Not World War III. But Foreign Conflicts May Get Uglier Before Election Day.
description: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague David Sanger, a White House and national security correspondent, has a look at what the widening conflict in the Middle East might mean for the presidential campaign. Plus, a Times photographer explains what she saw in Georgia this week with Vice President Harris. — Jess Bidgood

title: Trump’s False Claims About the Federal Response to Hurricane Helene
description: After Hurricane Helene battered several Southeastern states last week, former President Donald J. Trump wasted no time in criticizing President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris for the federal government’s response — often making false accusations.

title: Israel Expands Attacks on Hezbollah as Iran Warns of Retaliation
description: Less than a week after Israel killed Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, Israeli warplanes bombarded areas south of Beirut around midnight on Thursday, this time targeting his presumed successor.

title: Oklahoma Schools Need 55,000 Bibles. Trump-Endorsed Book Fits the Bill.
description: When the education superintendent of Oklahoma, Ryan Walters, ordered this year that every public school classroom in the state must have a Bible in the classroom, he didn’t mention any special requirements.

title: Harris, in Michigan, Tries to Head Off Trump’s Attacks Over Gas Cars
description: Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday sought to rebut a frequent argument from former President Donald J. Trump that she would mandate the end of gasoline-powered cars, issuing a rare direct response to her White House rival’s exaggerations and misleading claims.

title: Instructor at Troubled Skydiving Spot Gets 2 Years After Faking Credentials
description: A skydiving instructor who used someone else’s credentials to train people in tandem jumping at a troubled facility near Lodi, Calif., was sentenced this week to two years in prison.

title: 2 Men Sentenced to Prison for Attacking Officers at Jan. 6 Riot
description: A man from New Jersey and another from New York were sentenced to prison on Friday after federal prosecutors said they had breached the U.S. Capitol building and attacked law enforcement officers during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021.

title: Aides Say Trump Resisted Sending Federal Funds After California Wildfires
description: As California battled the deadliest wildfire in its history in 2018, Donald J. Trump, then the president, initially opposed unlocking federal funding for the state, according to two former Trump administration officials.

title: In North Carolina Town Hall, Trump Makes a Series of Promises to Appeal to Veterans
description: At the end of his town hall in North Carolina on Friday, former President Donald J. Trump was asked by a former Air Force pilot whether he would create a panel to keep “woke generals” out of the Defense Department.

title: A Deluge of Rain Poured Out of the Heavens. But There’s Still No Drinking Water.
description: Since their home lost running water around 2 p.m. on Sept. 27 from Hurricane Helene, Etiska Jackson and her husband, Jayme, have been driving back and forth between their home in Asheville, N.C., and her brother’s in Madison County, about 25 miles north. There, they wash their clothes, take showers and fetch water from a well to flush their toilet.

title: There Are Layers to This
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: 5 Takeaways From Melania Trump’s Book
description: Melania Trump’s new memoir offers a few new glimpses into a life she has carefully walled off from the public, but readers hoping to understand one of the most mysterious first ladies in modern history will not make it past the gilded front gate.

title: Biden Urges Congress to Replenish Disaster Relief Funds Quickly
description: President Biden urged members of Congress on Friday to provide emergency funding for the Small Business Administration, saying the agency is critically low on money needed to help people in communities devastated by Hurricane Helene.

title: Quote of the Day: Assistance Slow to Reach Hard-Hit Latino Communities
description: “We don’t have a lot right now, but we have each other.”

title: Behind Trump’s Views on Ukraine: Putin’s Gambit and a Political Grudge
description: On July 7, 2017, after President Donald J. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia shook hands in Hamburg, Germany, to conclude their first face-to-face meeting, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson walked out of the sterile conference room, removed notes from his pocket and gave anxious White House aides a summary.

title: Villages Spared a Soviet Nuclear Plant Are Split Over a U.S. One
description: It appeared to be a typical harvest festival on Poland’s picturesque Baltic coast, with women in traditional dress singing folk songs and local farmers displaying their wares.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: How a Gardener at a Brooklyn Park Spends Her Sundays
description: A decade ago, Eve Brooks was unemployed and looking for help. A caseworker mentioned that the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation had several job training programs, including a six-month horticulture program. She immediately enrolled.

title: Big Business Saw an Ally in Eric Adams, and Overlooked His Issues
description: It wasn’t quite love at first sight, but it did not take New York’s business elite long to embrace Eric Adams.

title: Ukraine’s Donbas Strategy: Retreat Slowly and Maximize Russia’s Losses
description: Throughout the year, Ukraine has lost a series of cities, towns and villages in its eastern Donbas region to Russia, typically withdrawing its troops after hard-fought battles that sometimes lasted for months.

title: Michigan Father Dies in Israeli Airstrike in Lebanon, Family Says
description: Kamel Ahmad Jawad remained calm, even as Israeli missiles rained down around him in his hometown in southern Lebanon, thousands of miles from his other home, Dearborn, Mich.

title: Deadly Marburg Virus Hits Rwanda’s Doctors and Nurses Hard
description: Rwanda’s fragile health care system could become overwhelmed by the deadly Marburg virus, doctors fear, because most of those currently infected are medical professionals, and some have already died.

title: A Nation of Homebodies
description: It turns out we aren’t just bowling alone — we’re bowling at home.

title: Can Hudson Square Reinvent Itself as New York City’s Next Hot Neighborhood?
description: New York City is full of distinct neighborhoods, many competing for charm, hipness, quality of life and a good work-life balance. As a newcomer, and one that many city dwellers still haven’t heard of, Hudson Square is trying to create an identity separate from its culturally vibrant neighbors — SoHo to the east, the West Village to the north, TriBeCa to the south — that have long had curb appeal for businesses and new residents alike.

title: Pro-Palestinian Group Is Relentless in Its Criticism of Israel, and It Isn’t Backing Down
description: Without even entering Grand Central Terminal’s soaring main hall on one Thursday evening in July, Nerdeen Kiswani and her pro-Palestinian protest group, Within Our Lifetime, managed to shut it down.

title: Campus Protest Investigations Hang Over Schools as New Academic Year Begins
description: With a new academic year well underway, more than 60 colleges and universities are still under federal investigation over antisemitic and Islamophobic incidents during the campus protests that swept the United States after the Oct. 7 attacks in Israel, according to the Department of Education.

title: How Walmart’s Donna Morris Manages the Largest Work Force in America
description: More than 30 years into a career that had brought her to California and then Arkansas from her native Canada, Donna Morris could not have chosen a more challenging time to take on the role of chief people officer of Walmart. It was February 2020 — a couple of weeks before the coronavirus pandemic upended the world and laid bare an uncertain future for both workers and the retail industry.

title: A Menace to Motorists, but the ‘Noble’ Moose Is Adopted by Newfoundland
description: Running into a moose when driving a car or truck is bad enough, but crashing into the giant animal while riding on two wheels can be worse.

title: GloRilla, Hip-Hop’s Master Motivator, Rounds Out Her Message
description: GloRilla is always on the clock these days. Last month, the rapper born Gloria Hallelujah Woods stomped and bounced through her hits “Yeah Glo!” and “TGIF” at the MTV Video Music Awards, then spent the next morning at a photo shoot.

title: Get Your Mind Into the Gutter
description: Last winter, after finding big puddles in our New Jersey home’s cellar for the third time, my wife and I called a local plumber. He gave the cellar a once-over, confirmed that our sump pump was in working order, and then surprised us by suggesting we take a look outside the house.

title: Ella Purnell Is a TV Star Who Hasn’t Lost Touch With Her Barista Roots
description: You might think twice about overlooking the office wallflower after watching Ella Purnell play a sad sack gone sadist on the new Starz dramedy “Sweetpea.”

title: Will the ‘SmartLess’ Podcast Be the Biggest Role of Their Careers?
description: It’s a warm Saturday afternoon in the middle of August, and the actors Jason Bateman, Sean Hayes and Will Arnett are gathered on the stage of the Stephen Talkhouse, a popular music venue in the Long Island summer resort town of Amagansett, telling stories and swapping insults with Howard Stern, the longtime radio personality.

title: As Lawmaker Claims Trump’s Shooting Was Inside Job, G.O.P. Indulges Him
description: He posits that there is a mole within Donald J. Trump’s Secret Service detail and warns that the former president should bolster his private security to “watch the watchers.”

title: Can My Building Replace Our Keys With QR Codes and Facial Scans?
description: Q: The owner of my Manhattan apartment building is implementing an access system that unlocks doors only with QR codes, biometrics data, or facial scans. This system compromises tenants’ privacy and restricts access to dog walkers and other contractors. It is said to be susceptible to hacking, exposing us to burglaries. We are concerned about the collection, destination, and privacy of our data. Can our landlord force us to adopt this system?

title: Campaigning for Harris, Women Share Their Abortion Stories With Neighbors
description: One by one, the women shared their stories.

title: Supporters Who Watched as Trump Was Shot Prepare to Welcome Him Back
description: When the balloons descended on Donald J. Trump at the finale of the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Jondavid Longo, the mayor of Slippery Rock, Pa., was on the floor of the arena. As a few balloons popped, he glanced at the other Pennsylvania delegates he knew who, like him, had been at Mr. Trump’s rally in Butler, Pa., five days earlier. More than one of them winced at the sound.

title: As Israel Attacks, Many Lebanese Feel Dragged Into Someone Else’s War
description: When Hezbollah announced that its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah, had been killed in an Israeli airstrike, the talk among many of the group’s Shiite Muslim followers was of defiance and vengeance.

title: The Espresso Martini Has Nothing on These 2 Drinks
description: Despite its name (and temperature), cold brew’s season extends far beyond summer’s last breath — especially when put to use behind the bar.

title: 30 Days Out, the Harris and Trump Campaigns Brace for ‘Trench Warfare’
description: As Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump begin the final 30-day push for the White House, they are locked in a neck-and-neck race from the Rust Belt to the Sun Belt.

title: How Gender Became the Election’s Crucial Fault Line
description: In an alternate universe, Nikki Haley is running for president against Kamala Harris in the true Year of the Woman. In our world, Haley is on the sidelines wishing Republicans would stop alienating a large swath of voters. “Donald Trump and JD Vance need to change the way they speak about women,” Haley said on “Fox & Friends” in September, when she was asked why Trump and Vance were trailing by 14 points among female voters. “When you call even a Democrat woman dumb, Republican women get their backs up, too.”

title: Where Trump and Harris Stand on the Economy
description: Here’s where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand on economic issues like inflation, taxes and more. Maggie Astor, who covers politics for The New York Times, looks at the candidates’ views, proposals and records.

title: With ‘Megalopolis,’ the Flop Era Returns to Cinemas
description: Just before previews began at a Lower Manhattan theater on a recent Saturday night, Tazer Army reflected on the Francis Ford Coppola movie “Megalopolis” before even seeing it.

title: Hit by Disaster? How to Get What You Deserve From Insurers or FEMA
description: If your home was damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Helene, the most daunting challenge may still be ahead: Getting your insurance company, or the federal government, to give you the money you’re entitled to receive.

title: Good News if You Want to Look ‘Demure’
description: Oversize bows where six months ago there was cleavage. Flouncy, lacy, columnar dresses instead of skintight styles. More knee-length shorts, fewer micro mini skirts.

title: In Final Stretch, Biden Faces Some of the Biggest Crises of His Presidency
description: President Biden was in the White House Situation Room on Tuesday morning, watching on video monitors as Iran fired waves of ballistic missiles at Israel. The wider war in the Middle East, which Mr. Biden had spent much of his presidency trying to avert, had arrived.

title: Paris Hilton Is Becoming a Fixture at Walmart
description: Paris Hilton is associated with many things — being an heiress, an entrepreneur, an activist and a Y2K fashion inspiration — but living on a budget is not often among them.

title: Experian Wants You to Carry Its Debit Card Around. Be Wary.
description: In what universe would anyone want to whip out a debit card with the name of a credit bureau on it?

title: Al Pacino Is Still Going Big
description: Al Pacino has been one of the world’s greatest, most influential actors for more than 50 years. He’s audacious. He’s outrageous. He’s Al Pacino, and I’m pretty sure you know what that entails.

title: After Helene’s ‘Historic’ Damage, Appalachian Trail May Need Years to Recover
description: As the scope of devastation caused by Hurricane Helene comes into focus, an American landmark that dozens of towns benefit from is facing historic destruction: the Appalachian Trail.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,205
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 483
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Ever-Shrinking Condos Are the Choice of Investors in Toronto and Vancouver
description: There is a group of Canadians who want to see house prices continue to soar: investors. A report from Statistics Canada released this week details their outsize influence on the condominium markets in Vancouver and Toronto. And it’s an influence that may now be thwarting some new construction.

title: Fear Factors
description: I was fascinated to discover recently that each October, my friend Alex undertakes a spooky-season film festival, endeavoring to watch one horror flick for each day of the month. I do not expect that his roster includes the 2012 documentary “Part of Me,” a chronicle of the musician Katy Perry’s California Dreams concert tour. But I happened to watch that film this week, and it made me contemplate what, exactly, makes a movie frightening.

title: Adoptions by Foreign Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: To Understand Trump vs. Harris, You Must Know These American Myths
description: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are making their appeals to the American electorate on the basis of personality, character and policy. But they are also framing themselves as actors in the American story — the events of the recent past and the deeper narrative of U.S. history carried by the symbol-rich stories of our national mythology.

title: JD Smirks His Way Into the Future
description: When I’ve covered the campaigns of women on presidential tickets, the question invariably arises: “Is she tough enough to be commander in chief?”

title: Benny Gantz: What the World Needs to Understand About Iran
description: Oct. 7, 2023, marked the worst tragedy for the state of Israel and the Jewish people since the Holocaust. Some 1,200 people were murdered in Israel, and approximately 250 people were taken hostage on a single day; 101 of those souls are still held captive in Gaza. Hezbollah in Lebanon began its attack on the north of Israel the very next day, forcing nearly 70,000 Israelis from their homes. Iran, launching attacks first on April 13 and again on Oct. 1, has sent millions of Israelis into the safety of their shelters.

title: Biden Sought Peace but Facilitated War
description: When Israel defied America’s appeals for restraint by invading Lebanon a few days ago, a reporter asked President Biden if he was comfortable with what had unfolded.

title: America Needs a President
description: Last week’s column was devoted to uncertainties about how the next president would handle the deteriorating situation in Ukraine, where America’s proxy and ally is slowly losing ground to Russia, while the United States seems trapped by its commitment to a maximal victory and unable to pivot to a strategy for peace.

title: I’m a Doctor. ChatGPT’s Bedside Manner Is Better Than Mine.
description: As a young, idealistic medical student in the 2000s, I thought my future job as a doctor would always be safe from artificial intelligence.

title: The Troubling Quiet of North Carolina’s Cell Service Outages
description: John Tressler stood next to what was left of his storm-battered deli, part of which had collapsed in the torrents of a raging river, and waited to meet a relief crew bringing a much-needed supply of food into Swannanoa, N.C.

title: 2 Books About Old Flames
description: Dear readers,

title: What to Know: How Israel Could Retaliate Against Iran
description: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

title: What an Escalating Middle East Conflict Could Mean for the Global Economy
description: For nearly a year since the Hamas attack on Israel on Oct. 7 and the start of the fighting in Gaza, investment strategists have warned that a wider war could break out in the Middle East, crimping the world’s oil supply and sending shock waves throughout the global economy.

title: ‘Nobody Wants This’ Pits Jewish Women Against ‘Shiksas.’ Nobody Wins.
description: The derisive word for a male gentile is “shegetz.” I didn’t know the term until I married one. Even though my family is 100 percent Jewish and my brother took a DNA test to prove it, up to that point, I had heard only the female equivalent of the word: “shiksa.”

title: Former Gov. David Paterson of New York Assaulted in Manhattan
description: David A. Paterson, a former governor of New York, and his stepson were injured in an assault on a Manhattan street on Friday evening, the Police Department said.

title: Trump Did Nothing to Stop the Mob
description: One of the key points in the unsealed legal filing presented by the special counsel Jack Smith in the criminal case against Donald Trump for conspiracy to subvert the 2020 presidential election is that both Trump and his allies were well aware that he had lost the election. The evidence, Smith says, shows that Trump knew he didn’t have a case. But rather than accept the verdict of the voting public, Trump led the effort to pressure officials to overturn election results.

title: My Go-To Weeknight Dinners
description: Hello, and thank you to Mia Leimkuhler for taking time off so I can go on and on about my favorite thing: recipes!

title: Hundreds of Storm-Ravaged Roads, and No Timeline for Fixing Them
description: The small roads made of dirt and rock had been there for generations, twisting byways that carried families up and down the mountains of western North Carolina. The asphalt highways were newer, built along cliffs and over rivers to connect the region with South Carolina and Tennessee.

title: The Problem With the Hurricane Category Rating
description: By the time Hurricane Helene reached western North Carolina a week ago, causing devastating floods, it was no longer a hurricane.

title: Milton Tracker: Latest on Storm's Path, Power Outages and Winds
description: See the likely path, evacuation orders and wind arrival times for Milton.

title: David Burnham, Times Reporter Who Exposed Police Graft, Dies at 91
description: David Burnham, a former investigative reporter for The New York Times whose exposé of corruption in the New York City Police Department in 1970 led to public hearings; tarnished top officials, including the mayor; and inspired the movie “Serpico,” about Mr. Burnham’s chief source, Detective Frank Serpico, died on Tuesday at his home in Spruce Head, Maine. He was 91.

title: Marvin Schlachter, Record Executive Who Championed Disco, Dies at 90
description: Marvin Schlachter, a music executive who helped launch Dionne Warwick and the Shirelles in the 1960s and who a decade later created one of the world’s most influential disco labels, bringing acts like Musique and France Joli to the masses, died on Sept. 19 in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Security Is Tighter for Trump Rally at Site of July Assassination Attempt
description: The U.S. Secret Service has deployed hundreds of agents and local law enforcement officials to guard former President Donald J. Trump when he returns to Butler, Pa., for a rally Saturday evening, hoping to seal up the holes that left him vulnerable to a would-be assassin at the same venue in July.

title: James Magee, Creator of a Mysterious Desert Monument, Dies at 79
description: James Magee, an enigmatic and idiosyncratic artist and poet who spent four decades building a starkly beautiful monument of stone and steel in the West Texas desert that may be the most significant artwork most people have never heard of, died on Sept. 14 at his home in Fremont, Mich. He was 79.

title: From Melania Trump: Modeling, Motherhood and a Brazen Whitewash of a Presidency
description: White House memoirs tend to go on a bit. Melania Trump’s is slim, as befits an erstwhile fashion model who prepared for her husband’s 2017 inauguration with “strong espresso and a light breakfast of fruit,” but gravely out of shape.

title: As 23andMe Struggles, Concerns Surface About Its Genetic Data
description: The genetic testing company 23andMe, once valued at $6 billion, is facing an uncertain future after a drop in share prices, a recent board resignation and a data breach last year that affected nearly seven million customers.

title: Widow of Man Killed in July Attack on Trump Returns for Rally
description: Helen Comperatore, the widow of Corey Comperatore, the former volunteer fire chief who was killed when a gunman tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump on July 13 at a rally in Butler, Pa., returned to the venue on Saturday when Mr. Trump came back for another rally.

title: Macron Calls for Halting Weapons to Israel for Gaza Conflict
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France called for an “immediate and lasting” cease-fire in Lebanon and said countries should stop shipping weapons to Israel for use in Gaza, adding to international pressure on Israel to do more to protect civilians and work toward an end to fighting in the region.

title: Missing People, Power Outages, Ruined Roads: Issues Across the Southeast After Helene
description: More than a week after Hurricane Helene made landfall as a Category 4 storm, state officials across the Southeast are scrambling to repair damaged electrical lines, roads and bridges affecting tens of thousands across the path of destruction.

title: Teacher’s Marks
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Kamala Harris Visits North Carolina to Check on Hurricane Response
description: Vice President Kamala Harris met with North Carolina and federal emergency officials on Saturday in Charlotte as she continued to help oversee the disaster response in the Southeast after Hurricane Helene.

title: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Lebanon as Fighting Spreads
description: As Israel escalated its fight against Hezbollah in Lebanon on Saturday, much of the Middle East was on edge, with many expecting an Israeli retaliatory strike on Iran as payback for its missile barrage on Israel earlier this week.

title: Harris Meets With Arab and Muslim Leaders in Michigan
description: Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday met with Arab and Muslim leaders while campaigning in Michigan, a crucial battleground state where roiling discontent over the United States’ backing of Israel’s war in Gaza and its escalating attacks in Lebanon could threaten her support.

title: Elon Musk Leaps to Trump’s Side in Rally Appearance
description: Elon Musk, the billionaire head of Tesla and SpaceX, strode onto the stage to cheers at Donald J. Trump’s rally on Saturday night, lifted his arms above his head and jumped into the air — twice — exposing his navel as his shirt rode up.

title: No Corrections: Oct. 6, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Trump’s Return to Scene of Attack Was a Do-Over in More Ways Than One
description: Donald J. Trump returned to Butler, Pa., on Saturday for a massive rally at the fairgrounds where he was struck in July by a would-be assassin’s bullet, an event envisioned by his campaign as a show of strength and a memorial for the former volunteer fire chief who was killed during the attack.

title: Corrections: Oct. 5, 2024
description: An article on Sept. 29 about the death of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah referred incompletely to the circumstances that led to military exchanges between Israel and Hezbollah starting last October. Hezbollah began firing on Israeli positions in solidarity with Hamas after the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel that ignited the war in Gaza.

title: Tunisia’s Autocratic Leader Is Poised to Steamroll to Election Victory
description: For many Tunisians, there seems to be little point to the presidential election on Sunday. There are barely any candidate posters, no debates and not much suspense. The president, Kais Saied, appears so sure of victory that he has not even issued any policy proposals.

title: Quote of the Day: After Helene’s Deluge, Ashville’s Water Crisis Has No End in Sight
description: “I’m not going to provide a timeline, and I’m not going to provide a timeline on when I’ll provide a timeline.”

title: Gaza’s Schools Are for Learning, Not for Dying
description: This article has been updated to include news developments.

title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Revisits the Vice-Presidential Debate
description: Last week, America got the answer to the question: Who would play the presidential and vice-presidential nominees this season on “Saturday Night Live”?

title: ‘I Was on an Uptown 1 Coming Home From My Job at a SoHo Restaurant’
description: Dear Diary:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
