title: Can the New York Liberty, the Best in the W.N.B.A, Finally Win It All?
description: Barclays Center in Brooklyn shook with the roar of 17,700 basketball fans, almost all of them rooting for the New York Liberty. They have been waiting years for a team like this one, and on Thursday, with only five minutes left and the Liberty up by 15 points over the Minnesota Lynx in Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. finals, there was a sense that the team’s run of failures was going to be over.

title: A Day in the Life of Tim Heidecker, Glendale Dad
description: From the moment he showed up at Tim Heidecker’s house, the Chihuahua in the dragon costume seemed a little freaked out.

title: A Test of Knowledge and a Winning Entrant
description: “Did you follow the news this week?” That’s how The New York Times News Quiz announces itself each weekend.

title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Harris and Trump Take Their Contest to ‘Family Feud’
description: Although former President Donald J. Trump refused invitations for a second debate with Vice President Kamala Harris, “Saturday Night Live” came up with another setting where both presidential nominees might share the stage: the game show “Family Feud.”

title: Corrections: Oct. 13, 2024
description: An article last Sunday about the growth of the “SmartLess” podcast misspelled the surname of the CAA executive who helped expand the podcast’s brand. He is Josh Lindgen, not Lingen.

title: Ladakh’s Local Hero Wants India to Pay Attention to His People
description: Sonam Wangchuk has worn many hats: as an engineer, an environmentalist and an education reformer.

title: Russian Strikes on Ukrainian Ports Target Civilian Shipping
description: Russia has stepped up its assaults on Black Sea port infrastructure and civilian shipping in recent days, in what Ukraine says is an attempt to disrupt its exports and damage its economy.

title: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Hispanic Likely Electorate
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

title: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Hispanic Registered Voters
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

title: John F. Kennedy Jr.’s 1990s-Era Magazine Is Back, With a QAnon Twist
description: On a Saturday morning in August, a few hundred people gathered at a convention center in Hot Springs, Ark., paying between $145 and $475 to hear from a cast of far-right speakers. They included a body builder-turned-pundit who carries a tomahawk and promotes an antisemitic conspiracy theory, and a pro-Trump preacher who has warned of threats posed by technologically sophisticated demon mermaids.

title: The Author of ‘The Curious Incident’ Is Back With More Dogs
description: The British writer Mark Haddon is best known for his 2003 novel “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” in which a neurodivergent teenage boy solves a murder mystery and wins the reader’s heart. Haddon is equally accomplished at creating gripping narratives and sympathetic characters in his shorter fiction. The stories in this splendid new collection are inspired by an eclectic variety of sources, including a novel by H.G. Wells, Virginia Woolf’s first published story and, as with some of Haddon’s previous work, Greek mythology.

title: Jokes and Offbeat Auctions for the Troops: Standup Comedy Sweeps Ukraine
description: Onstage in a Kyiv theater, Anton Tymoshenko tells a joke about Ukrainians who are never satisfied with the weapons their country gets from the West — if they got nuclear weapons, he says, they would probably grumble about the quality of the uranium. He mocks the Odesa mayor (for being allegedly pro-Russian) and the Kyiv one (for being allegedly pro-himself).

title: The Secretive Dynasty That Controls the Boar’s Head Brand
description: In May 2022, the chief financial officer of Boar’s Head, the processed meat company, was asked a simple question under oath.

title: Friends With Benefits, but Without Illusions
description: If you loved Miranda July’s “All Fours,” Knopf suggests, try Susan Minot’s “Don’t Be a Stranger.” How depressing. Minot is an O.G. writer of female desire who published the spare and potent “Lust and Other Stories” in 1989, when July was still in knee socks and Sally Rooney just a glimmer in Mr. Rooney’s eye. Its neon-lettered cover blazed from every cool girl’s bookshelf.

title: Can the Government Get People to Have More Babies?
description: In 1989, Japan seemed to be an unstoppable economic superpower. Its companies were overtaking competitors and gobbling up American icons like Rockefeller Center. But inside the country, the government had identified a looming, slow-motion crisis: The fertility rate had fallen to a record low. Policymakers called it the “1.57 shock,” citing the projected average number of children that women would have over their childbearing years.

title: Christopher Steele and the Mueller Team Are Still Trying to Set the Record Straight
description: Why is it that this year’s election feels encrusted with such déjà vu? Is it the outsize presence of Nate Silver? Former President Donald Trump’s presence on the ticket? Or maybe it’s because Kremlin interference appears to have been ramping up in recent months. In September, the U.S. State Department announced it was pulling out all the stops, offering $10 million for information on a group called Russian Angry Hackers Did It.

title: On the Trail, Harris Turns to Her Experience Fighting Cross-Border Crime
description: As Vice President Kamala Harris vows to crack down on illegal immigration at the nation’s southern border, she has played up her experience as California’s attorney general pursuing criminal groups that traffic drugs, guns and people across the United States and Mexico.

title: A Birth Scene So Taxing, Andrew Garfield and Florence Pugh Needed to Rest
description: You wouldn’t expect the romantic drama “We Live in Time” to have an action scene, but it does — at least that’s how Andrew Garfield sees it.

title: A Hedgehog, a Centrifuge and Other Millennial Life-Improvement Splurges
description: How much ongoing joy can you get from something that weighs eight ounces?

title: Once Known for Death Row, San Quentin Hosts a Star-Studded Film Festival
description: The prizes were paper certificates. The red carpet measured just a few feet long. The catered lunch spread was state-issued bologna sandwiches wrapped in plastic.

title: Who Is That You Are Chatting With? Oh, Just ChatGPT.
description: When you think of what a voice programmed by artificial intelligence would sound like, you might picture something robotic and stilted, with a staccato cadence incapable of capturing the inflections, speed and emotion required to sound even somewhat human. But this is 2024, and the robots have gotten a serious upgrade. Now they can imitate voices, accents and intonation to an almost creepy degree — for better or worse.

title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ and the Underappreciated Influence of Carol Burnett
description: What makes Lorne Michaels laugh?

title: GOP Is Making Inroads With Black and Hispanic Voters
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has gained some ground since 2020 among Black and Hispanic voters, especially men. Ruth Igielnik, who conducts polls for The New York Times, explains.

title: Harris Struggles to Win Over Latinos, While Trump Holds His Grip, Poll Shows
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s support among Hispanic voters is in dangerously low territory for Democrats, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll, while her rival, former President Donald J. Trump, has maintained his strength with the fast-growing group poised to play a key role in deciding control of the White House.

title: Why Is Trump Gaining With Black and Hispanic Voters?
description: In 2016, Donald J. Trump became the Republican nominee and ultimately won the presidency after calling many Mexican immigrants rapists and falsely claiming that Barack Obama was not born in the United States.

title: A Tale of Two Hurricanes Finds More That Differs Than Is the Same
description: Cindy Miller wasn’t sure where to begin the cleanup this weekend at her home in Englewood, Fla. Hurricane Milton had drenched her home and dumped debris everywhere. Much of it was not even hers. A sofa, doors and shoes littered the backyard, along with detritus that remained from Hurricane Helene, the deadliest hurricane to hit the U.S. mainland in nearly two decades.

title: The Connections Companion No. 491
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,213
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Hezbollah Drone Strike Kills 4 Israeli Soldiers on Military Base
description: A drone strike by Hezbollah on a military base in the north of Israel killed four soldiers and wounded dozens of other people, the Israeli military said Sunday.

title: Lawyers Should Not Assist Trump in a Potential Power Grab
description: As the presidential campaign begins its final sprint, Donald Trump has made crystal clear how he will respond if he loses. He will refuse to accept the results; he will make baseless claims of voter fraud; and he will turn, with even more ferocity than he did in 2020, to the courts to save him.

title: If the Pro-Life Movement Loses This One, Its Future Is in Danger
description: I’ll never forget the first time I heard my oldest daughter’s heartbeat. My wife was experiencing trouble in the first three months of pregnancy, and we were worried she was miscarrying. We rode together to her doctor’s office, full of anxiety. And then we heard the magical sound — the pulsing of our little girl’s tiny heart. We didn’t know if she would ultimately be OK, but there was one thing we knew: Our daughter was alive.

title: Ignore the Polls
description: Here’s a bit of advice to help maintain your sanity over the next few weeks until Election Day: Just ignore the polls. Unless you’re a campaign professional or a gambler, you’re probably looking at them for the same reason the rest of us are: to know who’ll win. Or at least to feel like you know who’ll win. But they just can’t tell you that.

title: A Shift in the World of Science
description: Technology observers have grown increasingly vocal in recent years about the threat that artificial intelligence poses to the human variety. A.I. models can write and talk like us, draw and paint like us, crush us at chess and Go. They express an unnerving simulacrum of creativity, not least where the truth is concerned.

title: Democrats to Fly Harris Ads Over N.F.L. Games in Swing States
description: As the Harris campaign continues to court male voters, it is dialing up a deep shot, targeting a venue where it thinks it will reach quite a few of them: professional football.

title: SpaceX Advances Starship Program With a Launch and a Catch
description: SpaceX pulled off a feat of technical wizardry on Sunday, not only flying a 233-foot rocket booster back to its launch site, but also catching it out of the air with two giant mechanical arms.

title: New York Can Do Better Than Andrew Cuomo
description: There are many ways for New York City to turn the page on Mayor Eric Adams.

title: It’s OK if You Haven’t Gotten Your Flu Shot Yet
description: Like many health care workers, I am required to receive my annual flu shot by the end of October. Every year, I wait until the last possible day to get vaccinated.

title: Can We Please Just Find the Aliens Already?
description: Picture an ice-covered landscape, rough and rocky. Plumes of water vapor erupt from the surface. Tendrils of algae lurk in the bright white glaciers. Deep below the surface, microorganisms and other creatures cluster near hydrothermal vents, fissures in the ocean floor where life can thrive.

title: This ‘Fake Sauce’ Is Truly Good
description: Good morning. There’s a term in Italian cooking, cucina povera. It translates literally as “kitchen of the poor,” but in practice means the kitchen of the frugal, the cooking of the thrifty and unwasteful. I think of it, myself, as the cuisine of the empty nester, of the dope who once again forgot to pick up sausages during the weekly shop, who doesn’t have a pound of ground beef in the freezer, who arrives at Sunday afternoon with only a decent pantry and a bunch of oldish vegetables in the crisper.

title: I Write My Obituary, So I Can Live a Better Life
description: To the Editor:

title: SpaceX Achieves Its First-Ever ‘Chopsticks’ Landing
description: SpaceX launched and returned a large rocket booster to its Texas site, catching it with mechanical arms in its first-ever “chopsticks” landing.

title: Abdul Salaam, Quiet Member of the Jets’ ‘Sack Exchange,’ Dies at 71
description: Abdul Salaam, an unassuming but important member of the ferocious Jets defensive line, known as the New York Sack Exchange, that preyed on quarterbacks in the 1980s, died on Tuesday in Cincinnati. He was 71.

title: U.S. to Deploy Missile Defense System and About 100 Troops to Israel
description: The United States is sending an advanced missile defense system to Israel, along with about 100 American troops to operate it, the Pentagon announced on Sunday. It is the first deployment of U.S. forces to Israel since the Hamas-led attacks there on Oct. 7, 2023.

title: After Hurricane Milton Left, My Town Revealed Itself
description: I spent most of my life in Green Bay, Wis., cheering on the Packers, frequenting supper clubs and becoming a pro in winter wardrobe layering. I was a Wisconsinite through and through and would have been happy to stay there the rest of my life.

title: Review: Philharmonic Pays Tribute to Schoenberg
description: When Arnold Schoenberg conducted the premiere of “Pelleas und Melisande,” his symphonic poem based on the somber fairy-tale that inspired Debussy’s opera, in 1905, it was in front of a hostile Viennese audience. Reviews were “unusually violent,” the composer would later recall, with one critic suggesting he be committed to an asylum and banned from all access to music paper.

title: Fisher-Price Recalls 2 Million ‘Snuga Swings’ After Five Infant Deaths
description: After at least five infants died while sleeping in a product made by Fisher-Price, the company has recalled more than two million of the product, the Snuga Swing, because it poses a suffocation risk, according to the recall.

title: The Painter Titus Kaphar Wanted a Bigger Canvas, So He Made a Film
description: We often scrutinize an artist’s work, searching for autobiographical clues. But in Titus Kaphar’s recent paintings, and in his new film, “Exhibiting Forgiveness,” such close reading is unnecessary. His life experience is laid bare, in all its poignant and — sometimes agonizing — pain.

title: Woman Who Tried to Smuggle 29 Turtles Wrapped in Socks Pleads Guilty
description: A woman pleaded guilty on Friday to attempting to smuggle 29 Eastern box turtles, a protected species, that were individually wrapped in socks inside a duffle bag as she tried to paddle in an inflatable kayak across a lake from Vermont to Canada over the summer, officials said.

title: The Ground Game: Harris’s Turnout Machine vs. Trump’s Unproven Alliance
description: In the final weeks of the 2024 election, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are staking their chances on two radically different theories of how to win: one tried-and-true, the other untested in modern presidential campaigns.

title: Biden Calls for Bipartisan Effort to Help Areas Hit by Storms
description: Standing in front of one of the many houses wrecked by Hurricane Milton in Florida, President Biden said on Sunday that the storm was devastating for those who lost homes, businesses or relatives, even as he expressed relief that the storm was not as destructive as anticipated.

title: Monday Briefing: The U.S. to Deploy Troops to Israel
description: The Pentagon said that it was sending an advanced missile defense system to Israel, along with about 100 American troops to operate it. It is the first deployment of U.S. forces to Israel since the Hamas-led attacks there on Oct. 7, 2023.

title: Just Over the Border from Israel, a Hezbollah Cache of Explosives and Mines
description: We had entered southern Lebanon early Sunday afternoon in a convoy of armored vehicles through a gap punched by Israeli forces in the snaking border wall.

title: One Who Walks the Walk
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Harris Sends a Secret Weapon to a Georgia Fish Fry: Bill Clinton
description: The smell of fried fish was lingering on Sunday afternoon, and there was Bill Clinton beneath a tree, wearing a Harris-Walz camouflage cap and edging closer and closer to his modest audience the longer he spoke.

title: Harris Suggests Trump Is ‘Weak and Unstable’ in Pointed Challenge
description: Vice President Kamala Harris challenged former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday for refusing to do what she has done in recent days: release a report on his health, sit for a “60 Minutes” interview and commit to another presidential debate.

title: A Little Bit of Power
description: On This Week’s Episode:

title: Man Is Arrested on Weapons Charges Heading to Trump Rally in Coachella, Officials Say
description: A man was arrested and accused of illegal weapons possession as he was trying to enter former President Donald J. Trump’s rally in Coachella, Calif., on Saturday evening, the Riverside County sheriff’s office said on Sunday.

title: China Holds War Games Encircling Taiwan in Warning to Island’s Leader
description: China held large-scale military drills in the waters and skies surrounding Taiwan on Monday, a show of force that signaled the growing threat of Beijing’s ability to choke the self-governing island that China claims as its own.

title: Harris Rallies in North Carolina
description: The vice president criticized former President Donald J. Trump, calling him “weak and unstable.”

title: Quote of the Day: Government Policies to Raise Fertility Rates Haven’t Led to Baby Booms
description: “Living with your mom is not the best romantic environment for finding your lifelong partner.”

title: How Israel’s Army Uses Palestinians as Human Shields in Gaza
description: After Israeli soldiers found Mohammed Shubeir hiding with his family in early March, they detained him for roughly 10 days before releasing him without charge, he said.

title: No Corrections: Oct. 14, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Wranglers’ and ‘Elsbeth’
description: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 14-20 Details and times are subject to change.

title: What China’s Leaders Grasp About Another Trump Term
description: At the beginning of the Biden presidency, many of us serving in the National Security Council gathered to read the intelligence and reached a key conclusion: The 2020s would be what we called the “decisive decade” in U.S. competition with China.

title: Monday Briefing
description: A drone strike by Hezbollah on a base in northern Israel killed four soldiers and wounded dozens of other people, the Israeli military said yesterday, in what some saw as evidence of a worrisome gap in Israel’s air defense systems. Cross-border attacks by the militants have continued despite heavy Israeli bombardments aimed at Hezbollah targets in Lebanon.

title: An Artist Signed Over His Career to Investors. Now He Wants It Back.
description: The “Main Agreement” was supposed to be the final agreement, a contract to end all other contracts between two investors and Bjarne Melgaard, a provocative Norwegian artist who had drawn notice at the 2011 Venice Biennale with an exhibition about a fictional movement of gay terrorists.

title: In Heated House Race, a Moderate Republican Goes Full Trump
description: Representative Marc Molinaro has spent his decades of public service building a reputation as a particular brand of New York Republican: a measured and courteous pragmatist more interested in responsible governing than in ideological battles.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: China’s Stock Markets Rebound on Promises to Help Businesses
description: Stock prices rose in China on Monday, as investors welcomed government signals of renewed attempts to counter weakness in the economy by borrowing more and easing oversight of the private sector.

title: Israel Attacks Tent Camp at Gaza Hospital
description: People worked through smoke and darkness to extinguish fires and look through debris following the deadly attack on Deir al-Balah.

title: Learning a Language, and a Few Life Lessons, in France
description: When I booked a one-on-one intensive language program in France, I envisioned a dreamy getaway, where I could practice French while getting to know Provence through the eyes of a local.

title: Kash Patel: The Magical Rise of a Self-Described ‘Wizard’ in Trump World
description: As President Donald J. Trump battled public outrage in the summer of 2019 over his effort to enlist Ukraine in digging up dirt on former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., he summoned a small group of top advisers to the Oval Office. Among them was Charles Kupperman, the deputy national security adviser, who was surprised to see a relatively low-level staff member in one of the four chairs arrayed before the president’s desk: Kashyap “Kash” Patel.

title: Russia’s Latest Target in Africa: U.S.-Funded Anti-Malaria Programs
description: The scientists sifting through thousands of genetically modified mosquito larvae in a laboratory in Burkina Faso were trying to stop the spread of malaria, one of the biggest killers on the African continent.

title: Why ‘Unbalanced’ Muscles Can Cause You Pain
description: When you head out for your daily run, with each stride you’re strengthening your quadriceps, your hamstrings and your upper calf muscles. The muscles on the sides of your hips, however, aren’t growing much.

title: I Froze My Eggs to Reclaim My Right to Rest
description: I watched the ultrasound screen as my OB-GYN counted my follicles, the egg-producing sacs in my ovaries. They looked like the black holes in NASA images. I had more than 30 inside me. The sight unnerved me. My doctor seemed excited. “Those are some juicy-looking ovaries!” she said.

title: How Healthy Is Broccoli?
description: Children may not want to hear this, but broccoli more than deserves its place on our plates. The florets and stems are filled with nutrients that help keep your heart and bones healthy — and may reduce the risk of cancer.

title: Why Controlling Blood Sugar Is Crucial for Your Health
description: More than one in three adults in the United States has prediabetes, higher-than-normal blood sugar levels that can lead to Type 2 diabetes. And more than one in 10 has diabetes, characterized by still higher blood sugar levels that can eventually lead to eye problems, heart disease, a stroke, nerve damage and other serious health issues.

title: A Fact Checker Reflects on Our Age of Political Lying
description: In 2002, Bill Adair, who was then a political reporter for The St. Petersburg Times, took note of a new neighbor on his block in Arlington, Va. Mike Pence had recently become a congressman, and moved in four doors down. Their families became fast friends, and Adair came to respect Pence, especially as a politician willing to live in hostile territory: Pretty much everyone else on the block was a Democrat.

title: In Rural Wisconsin, Race Is an Undercurrent of the Presidential Election
description: The signs are everywhere that Sauk County, Wis., is a divided place.

title: Food Is What We Have In Common. Why Don’t We Hear More From the Candidates About It?
description: In a surprising turn of events, the presidential candidates have been talking about food. Food can be a winning topic, but we need to hear much more.

title: The Toxic Sludge That Ate Tennessee
description: A concise summary of Jared Sullivan’s “Valley So Low” is offered halfway through the book by its hero, Jim Scott, a plain-talking, suspender-wearing, Skittles-addicted plaintiff’s lawyer: “They had a toxic tub of goop, and it blew up.”

title: American Sign Language Brings New Layers to ‘American Idiot’
description: Inside the Mark Taper Forum in downtown Los Angeles on a recent Wednesday, the air was saturated with stage fog and preshow jitters. The first performance of a revival of Green Day’s “American Idiot” was just hours away, and the choreographer Jennifer Weber had some final instructions for the cast members, who were wearing their costumes — combat boots, eyeliner, enough artfully ripped jeans to fill a Hot Topic — while they ran through dance movements onstage. Weber, microphone in hand, sang the song “Homecoming” as she demonstrated choreography:

title: A Painter With an Eye for the Ridiculous
description: When the Canadian artist Ambera Wellmann painted “Strobe” (2021), a Surrealist beach landscape measuring 30 feet in length, she had just moved to New York, where she’d found representation with Company Gallery. Before that, she’d produced relatively small works, but now she was thinking big. “New York loves sensationalism in a way that’s kind of refreshing,” she says. “People like to make a splash.”

title: Killing of Japanese Boy Leaves Chinese Asking: Is This My Country?
description: A Japanese boy was stabbed on his way to school in China on Sept. 18. That’s the date when, nearly a century earlier in 1931, Japan invaded China.

title: Polio Threatens Gaza Today. Tomorrow, It Could Be Cholera.
description: In August, health officials recorded the first case of polio in Gaza in more than 25 years, in an unvaccinated 10-month-old baby whose lower left leg became paralyzed by the virus. Sadness and frustration washed over me when I first heard the news. It is outrageous that polio — which is highly contagious and can cause paralysis, respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse and even death — has been permitted to reappear in Gaza after being nearly eradicated across the globe.

title: Formerly Classified Documents Get the Fine Art Treatment
description: While scouring the internet some years back for obscure images of foods from the 1970s, Matthieu Nicol, a photo researcher in Paris, happened upon a trove of freely available pictures recently declassified by the U.S. Army.

title: A Reporter’s Shield Law Is Vital to Prevent Abuses of Power
description: Governments often chafe at the presence of a free press. The reason is simple: A robust and independent news media keeps a sharp eye on government and, when necessary, exposes abuse of power, corruption, incompetence and waste.

title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Portland, Ore., Right Now
description: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free dishes.

title: How Wall St. Is Subtly Shaping the Harris Economic Agenda
description: When two of Vice President Kamala Harris’s closest advisers arrived in New York last month, they were seeking advice. The Democratic nominee was preparing to give her most far-reaching economic speech, and Tony West, Ms. Harris’s brother-in-law, and Brian Nelson, a longtime confidant, wanted to know how the city’s powerful financiers thought she should approach it.

title: America Needs More Children. JD Vance’s Shame Game Won’t Get Us There.
description: Despite concerns over the falling birthrate, especially on the right, the Times Opinion columnist David French recognizes that the push to have more families — and bigger ones — has become problematic. In this audio essay, French explains why he thinks the recent political conversation on the topic reveals “the worst form of natalism.”

title: In a Tight Presidential Race, Third-Party Candidates Present a Wild Card
description: With a month to go before what is widely expected to be an extraordinarily close election, an extra element of unpredictability looms: In every battleground state, there is at least one third-party or independent presidential candidate on the ballot.

title: The Wildly Subversive Music of Soviet Ukraine
description: Eugene Hutz still owns his copy of “Slayed?,” a 1972 album released the year he was born by the British bad boys Slade that his father purchased on the Ukrainian black market. Its spine is now lined with tape, its cover deeply ringed by the record inside. But for Hutz, 52, it remains a powerful talisman of rock ’n’ roll’s transformative potential, even amid oppressive regimes.

title: Russian Oil Flows Through Western ‘Price Cap’ as Shadow Fleet Grows
description: A plan hatched by wealthy Western nations to deprive Russia of oil revenue is largely faltering, a new report found, with the majority of the Kremlin’s seaborne oil exports evading restrictions that were supposed to limit the price of Russian crude.

title: Isaac Hernández Brings Leading-Man Vibes to Ballet Theater
description: It was Isaac Hernández’s second week at American Ballet Theater, and he was feeling achy from rehearsals. But as soon as the pianist began to play, his body and eyes snapped to attention. It was his big entrance. He rushed across the studio in series of jumps, legs thwacking together in the air. He turned with one leg extended to the side. He did a circle of leaps that almost brushed the walls. He made the space feel small.

title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: This four-bedroom, three-bath house is in the Lafayette Square Historic Protection Overlay Zone, a semi-gated neighborhood in central Los Angeles recognized for its well-kept, stately homes showcasing popular architectural styles of the 1920s and 1930s. On this block are a mix of Tudor-revival, Mediterranean-revival and Spanish-revival homes. Public elementary and middle schools are nearby, as is a branch of the Los Angeles Public Library.

title: They’re ‘Saturday Night Live’ … and You’re Not
description: It’s easy to get lost watching “Saturday Night”: Jason Reitman’s new film drops us backstage at a moment of maximum confusion — 90 minutes before the 1975 debut of a new NBC show called “Saturday Night.” At the center of all the hubbub is creator-producer Lorne Michaels (played by Gabriel LaBelle), who’s been the one constant at “S.N.L.” over most of the show’s 50 seasons. But what about all the other characters rushing about, wringing their hands over whether this show will actually make it to air? Here’s a guide:

title: Growing Darkness, October Light: A Backyard Census
description: There’s hardly a spot of color on the hardwood trees in our yard, but the light is glorious, as it always is in October, and the signs of fall are unmistakable. The pokeweed, in full berry-laden splendor at the end of September, has been reduced to drooping leaves and magenta stems. Likewise the beautyberry and arrowwood shrubs, each picked down to the woody stems by cardinals and blue jays and mockingbirds and all manner of other creatures in this small, teeming yard.

title: Three Weeks to Go, and That’s All Anyone Is Sure Of
description: Gail Collins: Bret, Kamala Harris sure seems proud of her gun ownership, doesn’t she?

title: Will Leopard Print Ever Go Out of Style?
description: Leopard print — indeed, all animal prints, including zebra, python, cow and many not actually found in nature — have been with us since our long-ago ancestors turned the pelts of the animals they killed for food into clothing. Its role as a signifier has changed according to time and context, but it has never really disappeared, even as fur itself has fallen out of favor. While the lion may be king of the jungle, the leopard, or at least the leopard’s spots, is the king of fashion.

title: The Trump Voters Who Don’t Believe Trump
description: One of the more peculiar aspects of Donald J. Trump’s political appeal is this: A lot of people are happy to vote for him because they simply do not believe he will do many of the things he says he will.

title: How Climate Disasters Are Making Mobile Homes a Huge Risk
description: By the time the murky brown water in the house reached his chest, Joe Rogers realized it was too late to leave safely. Then, in an instant, his mobile home shifted violently, creating a wave that swept up furniture and trapped his wife, Sandra, in their bedroom.

title: OpenAI Could Be a Force for Good if It Can Address These Issues First
description: OpenAI, the artificial intelligence start-up behind ChatGPT, is now worth as much as Goldman Sachs or AT&T. OpenAI has also said it intends to shed its status as a nonprofit to become a for-profit business within two years. Outside experts and its employees have expressed concern that as a result, the company will shy away from its founding purpose — to build safe A.I. to “benefit all of humanity” — in favor of earning profits for investors.

title: Fitting In Was Never Randy Newman’s Jam
description: Randy Newman was a nepo baby, a sprig of musical royalty. Three of his uncles were Hollywood film composers. One received 45 Oscar nominations and won nine times.

title: Can Charlotte, N.C., Deliver for Kamala Harris?
description: When Democrats try to explain why their party has lost every presidential and Senate race in North Carolina since 2008, they often point to an unexpected place: Mecklenburg County, which includes the deep-blue city of Charlotte.

title: 4 Creepy Books to Read This Halloween
description: Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of his personal favorite creepy books to read in October.

title: Where Polls Can Mess Up (and What Pollsters Do About It)
description: With less than a month until Election Day, you may be paying more attention to political polls, and starting to wonder how much you ought to trust them.

title: NASA Launches Europa Clipper to Explore an Ocean Moon’s Habitability
description: Europa Clipper, the biggest interplanetary spacecraft that NASA has ever built, lifted off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida early Monday afternoon.

title: They Helped Build the Temple. Now, They’re Bringing It to the Screen.
description: A man is falling from the sky. Even as he plummets, you can tell he’s a dancer: There is grace in the twisting of his wind-buffeted limbs. He lands not with a thud but a whisper, on the tips of his toes.

title: Meteorologists Face Harassment and Death Threats Amid Hurricane Disinformation
description: A meteorologist based in Washington, D.C., was accused of helping the government cover up manipulating a hurricane. In Houston, a forecaster was repeatedly told to “do research” into the weather’s supposed nefarious origins. And a meteorologist for a television station in Lansing, Mich., said she had received death threats.

title: State of the Race: A Close Race Gets Closer
description: Follow the latest updates on the 2024 election.

title: Harris Steps Up a Major Push for Black Voters
description: Vice President Kamala Harris made a sweeping push on Monday to energize Black voters, among whom she faces slipping support, unveiling a plan to bolster the finances of Black men, appearing in interviews with two Black media outlets and releasing a pair of ads in battleground states targeted to that crucial voting group.

title: Harris’s Final Challenge: Restore a Splintering Democratic Coalition
description: In the final weeks of the presidential campaign, Vice President Kamala Harris is contending with erosion within the Democratic coalition that put Barack Obama and Joe Biden in the White House, and growing more dependent on white voters who historically aligned more with Republicans.

title: Attention Kmart Shoppers: It’s Closing Time
description: When Chrissy Economos and Gloria McCourtney heard that the last full-size Kmart in the mainland United States was closing down, they knew they had to pay their respects, even if the store was more than 1,300 miles away.

title: Three Receive Nobel in Economics for Research on Global Inequality
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to Daron Acemoglu and Simon Johnson, both of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and to James Robinson of the University of Chicago.

title: The Connections Companion No. 492
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,214
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Inside an Unprepared Secret Service
description: After the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump in Butler, Pa., Congress held hearings on the failures of the Secret Service, and its director, Kimberly Cheatle, stepped down.

title: U.S. to Send Troops to Israel, and a Splintering Democratic Coalition
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: A Political Misdiagnosis
description: The Democratic Party has spent years hoping that demography would equal destiny. As the country became more racially diverse, Democrats imagined that they would become the majority party thanks to support from Asian, Black and Hispanic voters. The politics of America, according to this vision, would start to resemble the liberal politics of California.

title: Michigan Republican Blames ‘Proofing Error’ for Misleading Ad in Black-Owned Newspaper
description: Black state lawmakers in Michigan are calling on the state’s attorney general and a local county prosecutor to investigate the congressional campaign of Tom Barrett, a Republican, for an ad in a Black-owned newspaper that incorrectly listed Election Day as Nov. 6.

title: In Texas, Execution Looms Despite Questions in Shaken Baby Case
description: Texas is preparing for the execution this week of an autistic man, Robert Roberson, who was convicted of killing his 2-year-old daughter in a case that has drawn intense scrutiny for its reliance on a questionable diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome.

title: Can Wall St. Help Harris Win Pennsylvania?
description: Despite entering the presidential contest only about three months ago, Vice President Kamala Harris has shattered fund-raising expectations — in large part because she has managed to win over many of the business donors who had been lukewarm about President Biden.

title: Most Voters Have Been Offended by Trump. It’s Not Always a Deal Breaker.
description: The vast majority of voters across the United States say they have been offended at some point by former President Donald J. Trump. But a sizable number of those voters say that has not stopped them from supporting him.

title: Russia Is Clawing Back Land Taken by Ukraine This Summer
description: Russia has recaptured a few villages in its western borderlands that Ukraine invaded over the summer, threatening Kyiv’s hold on territory it views as crucial leverage for pushing Moscow toward negotiations to end the war.

title: Lilly Ledbetter, Whose Fight for Equal Pay Changed U.S. Law, Dies at 86
description: Lilly Ledbetter had worked for 19 years at a tire plant in Alabama when she was sent an anonymous note: her pay was as much as $2,000 a month less than what men were receiving in the same supervisory job.

title: Canada Expels Indian Diplomats, Accusing Them of Criminal Campaign
description: Canada accused the Indian government on Monday of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada, escalating a bitter dispute that began last year with an assassination of a Sikh activist.

title: ‘Literally the Quickest Dinner Ever’
description: Of all the frozen proteins you could thaw for an easy weeknight dinner, shrimp are about the speediest and most elegant. Just pour the icy crustaceans into a bowl of cool tap water and let them soften on the counter while you prep the rest of your ingredients. By the time the garlic has been chopped and the spices are lined up on your counter, all the shrimp need is a friendly pat dry with a clean kitchen towel and they’re ready to go.

title: Doctors, A.I. and Empathy for Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Apply Blush Like a Professional
description: “Blush is trending,” says the makeup artist Ernesto Casillas, referring to the product’s ongoing popularity on TikTok. “A lot of people are calling it ‘blush blindness’ when someone overapplies it.” For advice on creating a more nuanced look, we turned to three people well attuned to the product’s capabilities: the comedian, actress and “Saturday Night Live” cast member Chloe Fineman, known for her uncanny impressions; the American Ballet Theatre principal dancer James Whiteside, who returns to the stage this month for the company’s fall season; and Casillas, whose clients include the actresses Zendaya and Ayo Edebiri. Here are their tips.

title: Italian Court Overturns Women’s Acquittals in ‘Bunga Bunga’ Legal Saga
description: After 14 years, the 21 women accused of helping to cover up Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s evening bacchanals had hoped that their long legal saga over the so-called “Bunga Bunga” scandal might be over.

title: Trump and Harris Both Like a Child Tax Credit, but With Different Aims
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has made an expanded child tax credit central to her campaign, and former President Donald J. Trump boasts, “I doubled the child tax credit.” With a quick look, voters might think the child-rearing subsidy the rare matter on which the rival candidates agree.

title: Deadly Hezbollah Strike on Army Base Shows Israel’s Weakness Against Drones
description: Minutes before a deadly Hezbollah drone strike on an army base in northern Israel this weekend, Israeli police officers notified the Air Force about reports of a suspicious aircraft, the police said. They were told not to worry because the aircraft was Israeli, prompting the officers to close the case.

title: Amid a Water Crisis, England Asks: Who Should Be in Charge?
description: On its journey to the North Sea, the River Thames runs through Henley, a picturesque middle-class town about 35 miles west of London. The river is central to the town’s identity, which is known for its annual royal regatta and for being the location of the first boat race between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

title: Kamala Harris Sets an Interview With a Not-So-Friendly Outlet: Fox News
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has agreed to an interview with Fox News, the network said on Monday.

title: In Jordan, a ‘Stunning’ Discovery Under Petra’s Ancient Stone
description: By the time Dr. Richard Bates swept his radar device over the sandstone of Petra’s ancient Treasury building, it had been more than two decades since anyone had so deeply probed the stone city’s grounds.

title: Italy Sends Boat to Albania With Migrants Who Were Bound for Italian Shores
description: Italy sent its first boat carrying migrants to Albania on Monday, part of a plan to send migrants who are rescued in the Mediterranean by Italian ships to detention centers in the Balkan nation, where their asylum claims will be assessed.

title: What is the THAAD Antimissile System the U.S. Has Sent to Israel?
description: The United States has sent a THAAD advanced missile defense system to Israel to thwart more attacks by Iran and its allies. Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said on Monday that the system was in place and could be “put into operation very quickly.”

title: NASA Launches Mission to Study Jupiter’s Moon
description: Europa Clipper will study whether Europa, Jupiter’s fourth-largest moon, possesses ingredients and conditions favorable for life.

title: N.J. Transit Train Hits Tree on Track, Killing 1 and Injuring 23
description: One person was killed and nearly two dozen others were injured in South Jersey on Monday morning when a New Jersey Transit light rail train struck a tree on the tracks, the commuter rail said.

title: Another Trump Clemency Recipient Faces Domestic Violence-Related Charges
description: A Florida man who received a commutation of a 20-year fraud sentence from President Donald J. Trump in 2020 — only to plead guilty this year to a related crime — was arrested on Sunday on domestic violence-related charges in South Florida.

title: New Jersey Transit Train Hits Tree on Track, Killing Train Operator
description: Nearly two dozen people were injured when the light rail train collided with a chunk of tree in South Jersey.

title: Read the document
description: Here are the records from Miami-Dade jail where Mr. Esformes was held after his arrest.

title: Conservative Activist Seizes on Passages From Harris Book
description: The conservative activist Christopher Rufo published claims on Monday that Vice President Kamala Harris had copied portions of her 2009 book “Smart on Crime,” citing five sections that he said were lifted from widely available sites including Wikipedia and news reports.

title: How Door Knocking Is Going in a Wisconsin Swing County
description: Follow the latest news from the Harris and Trump campaigns.

title: A Harris Ad Uses the Hurricanes to Try to Inflict Damage on Trump
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign began running this 60-second ad called “Safety and Security” on television stations in Georgia and North Carolina on Thursday and has spent about $75,000 to air it so far in markets affected by the recent hurricanes, according to AdImpact. The biggest expenditures have been in Charlotte, Raleigh and Asheville, N.C.

title: Survivors of Gaza Hospital Blaze Say They Are Living a ‘Recurring Nightmare’
description: This was not the first time that displaced Gazans camping on the grounds of Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital awoke to Israeli strikes on the place where they were trying to find safety. But Monday’s strike overshadowed any they had survived before: flames jumping from tent to tent, shrieks of agony and bodies so charred they were unrecognizable.

title: Armed Man Arrested After Reportedly Threatening FEMA Workers
description: A North Carolina man was arrested on Saturday and accused of threatening federal emergency responders who have been administering aid since Hurricane Helene ravaged parts of the state last month.

title: Ethel Kennedy, Matriarch of Family Dynasty, Honored at Cape Cod Funeral
description: About 200 people, along with prominent members of the Kennedy family, crowded into a Catholic church on Cape Cod on Monday for the funeral of Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and a powerful figure in the family’s political dynasty.

title: Lillian Schwartz, Pioneer in Computer-Generated Art, Dies at 97
description: Lillian Schwartz, who was one of the first artists to use the computer to make films and who helped bring together the artistic, scientific and technology communities in the 1970s by providing a glimpse of the possibilities at the intersections of those fields, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

title: America Is on the Brink of a Great Political Realignment. It’s Already Visible in Arizona.
description: One day each month, Charlie Kirk, one of the country’s most influential Republican activists, holds an event called Freedom Night in America at Dream City Church, a Pentecostal megachurch on the outskirts of Phoenix. “I truly believe that God has voted early in this election,” he said on a Wednesday in early October, addressing well over 1,000 people from a stage bathed in red, white and blue lights. “I believe that God voted early on July 13, when he spared the life of Donald Trump.”

title: Tuesday Briefing: India Accused of Homicide and Extortion
description: Canada accused the Indian government yesterday of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada. Canada also expelled Sanjay Kumar Verma, India’s top diplomat, and five others, saying they were part of a vast criminal network.

title: Tent Camp in Gaza Engulfed by Flames After Israeli Strike
description: Israeli strikes in the Gaza Strip killed Palestinians in a tent encampment on the grounds of a hospital and in a school turned shelter, according to residents and U.N. officials, as deadly fighting also raged between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon.

title: York Theater Artistic Director Out After ‘Hurtful’ Diversity Comments
description: The longtime leader of the York Theater Company, a small New York nonprofit known for its emphasis on musical theater, is acknowledging making “hurtful” comments about diversity that he says prompted his abrupt departure from the organization.

title: 50 Years After Killing, a Berlin Court Convicts a Stasi Officer of Murder
description: It was a brutal act from another time, almost another world, when the Cold War was hot and Germany was divided: An officer of East Germany’s feared secret police shot and killed a man trying to cross into the West.

title: Canada Accuses Indian Diplomats of Criminal Activities
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau accused the Indian government of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada. Canada expelled India’s top diplomat and five others. India denied the allegations.

title: Trump Has Become Unmoored in Time
description: This is the second in an occasional series about Donald Trump’s statements and language and what’s at stake in the election.

title: Ka, Lone Soldier of New York’s Underground Rap Scene, Dies at 52
description: Kaseem Ryan, who built a small but fervent following as an underground Brooklyn rapper known as Ka while maintaining a career as a New York City firefighter, died on Saturday. He was 52.

title: Therapeutic Food Shortage Puts African Children at Risk of Starvation, U.N. Agency Says
description: Nearly two million children may die of malnutrition because a product used to treat the condition is in short supply, the United Nations Children’s Fund said on Monday.

title: 2 Men Accused of Killing 72-Year-Old While Posing as Utility Workers
description: Two men posing as utility workers looking for a gas leak killed a man and bound his wife with duct tape after being admitted to their home in an upscale Detroit suburb on Friday, the authorities in Michigan said.

title: Corrections: Oct. 15, 2024
description: An article on Monday about mail ballot regulations described incorrectly Pennsylvania procedures for detecting whether mailed-in ballots are properly enclosed in privacy sleeves. Election officials can check for the sleeves using pre-punched holes in ballot envelopes before Election Day; they do not have to wait until they open the envelopes on Election Day.

title: Steely Determination
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Harris Uses Trump’s Own Words to Attack Him as ‘Unhinged’: ‘Roll the Clip’
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s words thundered from screens at a packed campaign rally on Monday night in Erie, Pa. But the event was for Vice President Kamala Harris, who was using Mr. Trump’s own words as her campaign amplified warnings of the dangers she says he poses should he win a second term in the White House.

title: Trump Bobs His Head to Music for 30 Minutes in Odd Town Hall Detour
description: Donald J. Trump was about 30 minutes into a town hall Monday night in suburban Philadelphia when a medical emergency in the crowd brought the questions and answers to a halt. Moments later, he tried to get back on track, when another medical incident seemed to derail things, this time for good.

title: Quote of the Day: Kmart Shelves Emptied of All But Nostalgia
description: “It is the final chapter in the great American story of success and failure.”

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Dozens of Palestinians were injured or killed by Israeli strikes in central Gaza yesterday morning, one of which hit the grounds of Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital, according to health officials and the U.N.

title: The Defendants in France’s Rape Trial Are Telling Us Something Horrifying
description: It’s the case that has transfixed France. Prosecutors say that for almost a decade, Dominique Pelicot repeatedly drugged his wife and invited strangers to join him in raping her. The prosecutors say that she was assaulted by dozens of men as she lay unconscious and that her husband filmed most of the encounters and then filed the videos in digital folders, including one titled “abuse.”

title: Late Night Is Still Waiting for Trump’s Medical Report
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Understanding Canada’s Fight With India Over a Murdered Sikh Activist
description: Canada expelled six Indian diplomats on Monday, including India’s High Commissioner to Canada, accusing them of being part of a broad criminal network to intimidate and harass Canadian Sikhs. India responded by kicking out six Canadian diplomats.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: They Were Driving Through a Tunnel. Then the Water Rushed In.
description: Titus Ogilvie-Laing was driving through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel last month in his beekeeping company’s van when he spotted something alarming. A stream of water was blasting out of the ceiling and pouring onto the enclosed roadway.

title: Word of the Day: concurrent
description: The word concurrent has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 13 in “Missing a Global Climate Target Could Spell Disaster for These Polar Bears” by Austyn Gaffney:

title: How a Man Imprisoned in New York Could Sway a Key House Race in Alaska
description: In the race for Alaska’s sole seat in the House of Representatives, candidates are defined by credentials specific to the state.

title: Fanfare for a Common Building
description: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at an apartment building that’s celebrating its 100th birthday. We’ll also look at a congressional race in upstate New York with a Republican whose rhetoric belies the careful, courteous and pragmatic reputation he spent years cultivating.

title: The Night Sky
description: Last week, people in parts of the northern hemisphere caught a rare glimpse of the aurora borealis, also known as the northern lights. The visual display was set off by a geomagnetic storm.

title: Iranian General Is Seen in State Media After Questions Over His Whereabouts
description: After days of speculation about his whereabouts, Brig. Gen. Esmail Ghaani, the commander of Iran’s elite Quds Force, appeared in video footage broadcast by Iranian state news media and in photographs from independent news outlets on Tuesday.

title: The Brutal Reality of Panda Breeding
description: Panda breeding has been highlighted as one of the big success stories in conservation: U.S. and Chinese scientists working together to increase the number of pandas released into the wild. But a New York Times investigation found that they have succeeded only at making more pandas for zoos. Individual pandas have been hurt in the process, and at least one has been killed. Mara Hvistendahl, an investigative reporter for The Times focused on Asia, explains how records, photographs and videos — many of them from the Smithsonian Institution Archives — offer the most detailed, unvarnished history of the program.

title: The Final Chapter
description: How do you cope when an abusive family member becomes terminally ill?

title: How Do You Say Goodbye to an Abusive Family Member?
description: When I was 19 years old, I cut ties with my father. I had a difficult, painful childhood, and I needed distance from him in order to heal. When I was 29 years old, I learned he had received a terminal diagnosis, and I had to confront the relationship I’d tried to leave behind.

title: Ann Patchett: The Decision I Made 30 Years Ago That I Still Regret
description: Tee Minot, the owner of Christopher’s Books in San Francisco, wrote me a letter not long ago about the joys of owning a bookstore. In the end, she said that if she could recommend one book to me, it would be “This Is Happiness,” by Niall Williams. I checked the shelves of my own bookstore, Parnassus Books in Nashville, doubting we’d have a copy of a paperback from 2019, but there it was.

title: Why Are People Wearing Bedroom Slippers on City Streets?
description: In the summer of 2018, Justin Bieber made a habit of walking around New York City in what looked like hotel slippers. He’d worn them out before, but by then he went seemingly everywhere in a plush white pair: To grab a coffee, to a church service at Hillsong, even to the beach. The choice baffled fans. Why was a multimillionaire wearing something that many hotel guests get for free? And did he not care about dirt? He remained undeterred. Later he incorporated the accessory into his streetwear brand, Drew House, ultimately paving the way for what has become one of the biggest trends of the past year. If members of the fashion world were confused by outdoor slippers then, they have since embraced them as an answer to our post-pandemic longing for home comforts.

title: A House for One That Has Room for Many
description: When Susan K. Reed bought a house in North Haven, N.Y., in 2002, she viewed it as a fun escape from her primary home in Brooklyn.

title: Is Bone Broth Really Brimming With Health Benefits?
description: Q: I’ve heard that bone broth has a ton of health benefits. Is there any truth to that?

title: A Girl’s Death Sets Up This Novel’s Mystery: Did the Maid Do It?
description: In Alia Trabucco Zerán’s second novel, “Clean,” a 7-year-old child has died. Estela García, the maid for a wealthy family in Santiago, Chile, sits alone in her cell, pleading her case to the authorities who might be listening: “I’m going to tell you a story, and when I get to the end, when I stop talking, you’re going to let me out of here.”

title: China Counts Wild Pandas. Nobody Believes Its Tally.
description: American zoos point to a rise in the wild panda numbers — 1,864 at last count — as proof that the tens of millions of dollars they have spent on conservation have hit their mark.

title: Alvin Ailey’s Silky Creatures of the Night
description: This portion of the dance is set to the second movement of Duke Ellington’s three-part “Night Creature.”

title: The Law Enforcement Officers With Surprising Power
description: Four years ago I drove to a small town in rural Missouri to meet the parents of Billy Ames, who were suing the St. Francois County Sheriff’s Department over his death. An autopsy said the cause was a meth overdose, and jailers admitted they had strapped Mr. Ames to a restraint chair. While reporting on the case for The Marshall Project, I learned that other facilities had banned restraint chairs, medieval-looking devices that experts say can make it harder to spot a medical crisis.

title: Political Infighting Hampers Ukraine’s Efforts to Avert Energy Crisis
description: For more than two years, as Russia relentlessly bombed Ukraine’s power stations, the head of the national electricity company, Volodymyr Kudrytskyi, earned praise from Kyiv’s allies and energy experts for keeping the country’s power grid mostly running.

title: His Blood Test Predicted Felonies in His Future
description: If you’re brazen enough to slap “A Comedy” on the cover of your novel, it had better be funny. Thankfully — for the reader, for the author, for everyone involved — Charles Baxter’s “Blood Test” is.

title: Neal Stephenson’s New Novel Traces the Making of a Spy
description: When the final twist of a novel leaves you more excited about pages yet to be written than the ones you’ve just read, the immediate temptation is to downgrade the pleasures you’ve experienced along the way. That’s the conundrum of assessing Neal Stephenson’s “Polostan,” an enjoyable book in its own right, but a trifle disappointing for the way it abruptly ends just as your interest is peaking in its intriguing main character.

title: Caves, Waterfalls and Loretta Lynn’s Ranch: Three Day Trips From Nashville
description: Little more than a decade ago, Nashville, a.k.a. Music City, wasn’t so much a tourist town as it was a destination for musicians — a place where performers like Taylor Swift could still play the Bluebird Cafe without creating a scene.

title: Need Help Understanding the Election? Try These Audiobooks
description: To read about a presidential election is to parachute into a nation grappling with what it has become — and what it wants to be. This fall, as voters face a choice between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump, the stakes can feel almost unbearably consequential. But it may be comforting to know that we have been here before: the rivets of American society straining, the national conversation devolving into a shouting match.

title: A Watch Took 6,000 Hours to Make. It’s Still Inspiring New Variations.
description: In 1744, at age 12, Jean-Marc Vacheron, the youngest son of a master weaver, began apprenticing for a prominent Swiss watchmaker. Eleven years later, he opened his own workshop in Geneva’s Saint-Gervais quarter, where he would eventually design his first key-wound pocket watch featuring movement wheels and hands intricately carved into swirling gold arabesques and an enamel dial marked with Roman numerals. But it wasn’t until 1819, likely while traveling through what is now Italy, that Vacheron’s grandson Jacques Barthélémi Vacheron met the Genevan watchcase salesman François Constantin; the two competitors quickly became partners. Constantin suggested adding jewelry to their timepieces to attract additional clients and, a few years later, their bejeweled creations — featuring amethysts, rubies and garnets — caught the attention of Prince Borghese and Victor Emmanuel I, the former king of Sardinia. At first, their watches for women were often embellished with gilded floral motifs and worn around the neck or pinned to gowns as brooches.

title: Telling the Stories of Wrongful Convictions, One Painstaking Case at a Time
description: Jim McCloskey should be a household name. Years before the Innocence Project began showing Americans that their prisons hold countless people who have committed no crime, he was quietly gumshoeing his way through hard, obscure cases. Without him, it’s hard to imagine “Serial” or “Making a Murderer” or the rest of our current wave of prosecution-skeptical nonfiction.

title: In These D.I.Y. Groups, ‘You Don’t Have to Prove That You Belong’
description: Kayla Nelson was perched on a ladder in her bedroom installing picture-frame molding in a recent Instagram Reel. The rhythmic guh-gunk of the nail gun she was using was overridden by the soundtrack of Megan Thee Stallion’s “Where Them Girls At.”

title: I Ate at Every Carbone in America. Was It Worth the Trip?
description: Carbone is a luxury brand, a celebrity beacon, a theatrical production, an indoor theme park celebrating the meatball-topped maximalism of Italian American cuisine and pop culture.

title: Tim Berne, a D.I.Y. Jazz Institution
description: For the saxophonist and composer Tim Berne, the Brooklyn bar Lowlands is a favorite neighborhood hangout. Lately, it has also become his musical laboratory.

title: The Mystery That’s Too Good to Solve
description: Six years ago, during a trip to the seaside town Margate, England, my family and I visited a site known as the Shell Grotto. When it first opened to the public, in 1838, it was advertised as an unexplained mystery. Apparently workmen had stumbled upon the “curious and interesting sight” while digging in the garden of a cottage. Further investigation revealed a subterranean network of passages and a chamber covered in approximately 4.6 million seashells, laid out to form a 2,000-square-foot mosaic spanning walls and archways and a domed shaft that lets in a narrow beam of light. Today the shells — round winkles, long razor clams, mussels, other less familiar specimens — are mostly faded in color, some blackened with dirt.

title: What Should a Music Magazine Be in the TikTok Era? Pitchfork Alumni Have an Idea.
description: For more than a quarter century, Pitchfork was a kind of Rolling Stone for the millennial generation, a bible for audiophiles whose authority was summed up by its simple slogan: “the most trusted voice in music.”

title: What a Crackdown on Immigration Could Mean for Cheap Milk
description: Four-thirty in the morning felt numbingly cold in southern Idaho when it was Rosa’s turn to usher the cows into the milking parlor. Striding through the dairy farm’s open lots, she tried to balance speed with caution. April showers and the hooves of roughly 2,000 cows had transformed whole sections of the lots into a slippery goo of dirt, dung and urine. The muck stuck to her rubber boots; it was treacherous. On at least one occasion, she had fallen in it.

title: Want More Inflation? Go Ahead, Let Presidents Meddle With the Fed
description: Former President Donald Trump wants a say in monetary policy decisions. He has tried to clarify that his goal is simply to give his opinion. But we know that he was upset with and opposed to the Federal Reserve’s recent decision to lower interest rates by half of a percentage point and that he toyed with firing the Fed’s chair, Jerome Powell, in his first term. Moreover, Mr. Trump’s supporters apparently have compiled a list of proposals that give the former president new ways to exert influence.

title: Where Trump and Harris Stand on Immigration
description: Maggie Astor, a politics reporter for The New York Times, breaks down where former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris stand on immigration.

title: Political Theater: 7 Shows That Wrestle With Cultural Issues
description: The stage has always been a political setting, whether explicitly or implicitly. The lights go down, and confrontation and conflict ensues. With the U.S. presidential election around the corner, and the political fractures of society on full display, recent theater productions have grappled with these difficulties head-on. Here are a few of the current and upcoming productions tackling loaded and thorny issues.

title: What’s So Funny About a Dictator? Venezuela’s Comedians-in-Exile Have Ideas
description: Estefanía León, a young Venezuelan comedian, once wondered how she could keep making jokes amid so much tragedy.

title: A 21-Year-Old Violinist Emerges From a Field Crowded With Prodigies
description: The stage of the Felsenreitschule, a theater carved from the side of a mountain in Salzburg, Austria, is about 130 feet wide. During concerts, artists come out from catacombs at the side, beginning a walk to the center that, depending on nerves, can feel punishingly long.

title: The Hard Truth About Montana and Jon Tester’s Senate Race
description: “This election is about making sure we can have a state that is the same state that we grew up in,” Senator Jon Tester warned a group of Montanans packed into a local Democratic field office in Great Falls one chilly evening last month, just 35 days from Election Day. Ticking through priorities like protecting rural health care and supporting veterans, he noted, “You can’t get all this stuff done with somebody who doesn’t really understand Montana.”

title: Tina Brown, the Queen of Legacy Media, Takes Her Diary to Substack
description: For some prominent writers, joining the newsletter platform Substack has become a declaration of independence from traditional news organizations, or an ambitious attempt to build a new model for publishing.

title: Can the Stock Market Keep Going Up? Market Watchers Think So.
description: Stocks have climbed since the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates a month ago, with investors betting that it marked the beginning of a series of cuts that will offer a tailwind to the market.

title: Should Human Sports Referees Be Mostly Replaced With Automated Ones?
description: Do you play or watch sports? Have you seen a referee or umpire make a really bad call? Have those bad calls ever made you wish a computer was making the calls instead of a person?

title: The Panda Factories
description: In the 1990s, China began sending pandas to foreign zoos to be bred, in the hope that future generations could be released into the wild. It hasn’t gone as planned.

title: Two Opinion Columnists on Melania Trump’s Memoir
description: Melania Trump promoted her recent memoir, “Melania,” with a series of glossy and cryptic promotional videos stating the desire “to share my perspective: the truth.” But what does the self-titled memoir reveal to us about the often inscrutable former first lady? The bookish Opinion columnists Carlos Lozada and Pamela Paul discuss what they learned — and often, what they did not — from her work.

title: Harris Has Raised $1 Billion. Can She Get Donors to Give More?
description: When 300 top fund-raisers for Vice President Kamala Harris filed into Philadelphia’s Academy of Fine Arts on Sunday evening for a 10-to-a-table dinner, they got to hear from Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Jaime Harrison, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Trump’s Border Plans Are Light on Details but Strong on Fury
description: During a rally in Arizona on Sunday, former President Donald J. Trump left out a crucial detail when promoting his proposal to hire 10,000 new agents to patrol the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: As Harris Visits Detroit, Some Democrats See Ground To Be Made Up
description: The playbook for Democrats in Michigan has been the same for decades. To carry the crucial swing state, they need to run up huge margins in its largest city, Detroit, where President Biden received 94 percent of the vote in 2020.

title: These Twin Marvels of Art Conservation Are Now Seen as Looted Works
description: Their restoration has been embraced as a remarkable testament to the skill of art conservators who identified disparate, ancient pottery fragments and used them to recreate the treasures of antiquity.

title: Lebanon’s Hospitals Buckle Amid Israel’s Offensive Against Hezbollah
description: It was 12:54 a.m., and Elie Hachem had not slept in days when the chief nurse at his Beirut hospital called him in a panic.

title: The Connections Companion No. 493
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,215
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Two Blue States That Will Determine Control of Congress
description: This year’s presidential race looks certain to be won or lost in a handful of swing states where neither party has a clear advantage.

title: Optimism on Wall Street, and Harris Agrees to a Fox News Interview
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Republican Operatives Function as Hidden Hand Behind Pro-Trump Efforts
description: A group of Republican donors and operatives has been the hidden hand behind some of this campaign’s most controversial advertisements attacking Kamala Harris and bolstering Donald J. Trump.

title: Hong Kong Investigates After 9 Monkeys Die in a Zoo
description: The deaths of nine monkeys at a Hong Kong zoo over two days have prompted officials to close part of the zoo as they investigate.

title: K-Pop Star Testifies in South Korean Parliament About Bullying at Work
description: It is rare for voices of dissent to emerge from within the tightly-controlled K-pop industry. So when one of its hottest stars was set to speak out about bullying in the workplace at a hearing in South Korea’s Parliament, expectations were high.

title: The Battle Over Who Controls the Internet
description: For years, the battle between governments and tech giants has played out behind the scenes.

title: Israel Tells U.S. It Won’t Hit Iran’s Oil or Nuclear Sites in Next Attack, Officials Say
description: The Israeli government has told the Biden administration that it will avoid striking nuclear enrichment and oil production sites when it makes its initial response to Iran’s recent missile attack, two officials said on Tuesday.

title: Prediction Markets Tell a Different Story From the Polls
description: Polls show the U.S. presidential contest as neck and neck. But a popular new way of tracking the race — and betting on it — is telling a different story.

title: Boeing Seeks to Line Up Billions in Financing as Strike Goes On
description: Boeing on Tuesday announced steps to improve its financial position as costs mounted and a strike by its largest union entered its second month.

title: A Philosophical Journey With Clicks of a Mouse
description: Reflecting on mankind’s long history with technology, the British philosopher John Gray makes a bracing assertion in his book “Straw Dogs”: “Technology is not something that humankind can control. It is an event that has befallen the world. Once a technology enters human life — whether it be fire, the wheel, the automobile, radio, television or the internet — it changes it in ways we can never fully understand.”

title: Paris Is Rising as an Art Market Hub, With Some Way Left to Go
description: “This is the Mona Lisa of handbags,” said Aurélie Vassy, Sotheby’s head of handbag and fashion sales in Europe, as she unlocked a glass display case and proudly revealed a battered black leather Birkin.

title: With Trump Facing Threats, Security and Politics Intersect as Never Before
description: He has been the target of two would-be assassins in a matter of months. The intelligence agencies have told him that Iran is still threatening to kill him, and Iranian hackers got into the email accounts of his aides.

title: Do You Know Where These Memorable Detectives Live?
description: Many crime novels are known for their enduring characters who keep coming back for more adventures. Can you place these five sleuths on their home turf?

title: Profits Leap at Goldman Sachs as Banks See Steady Economy
description: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported a monster jump in its third-quarter earnings, reaping $3 billion in profits — far higher than what Wall Street analysts had expected.

title: Trump Leans On Creative Bookkeeping to Keep Up in Cash Race
description: Donald J. Trump’s political operation has been taking extraordinary measures in a bid to stay financially competitive with Vice President Kamala Harris, deploying aggressive and creative accounting strategies that test the legal limits of how far a candidate can go to offload the core costs of running for president.

title: Trudeau’s Move Casts Light on the Reach of India’s Intelligence Agencies
description: The accusation by Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, that the Indian government orchestrated a campaign to threaten and kill Sikhs on Canadian soil has cast a spotlight on the potential reach of India’s shadowy intelligence network, which has been known to operate mainly in South Asia.

title: Walgreens Says It Will Close 1,200 Stores
description: Walgreens plans to close about 1,200 stores over the next three years, its parent company said on Tuesday, in an effort by the struggling pharmacy giant to cut costs and change focus.

title: Chinese Automakers Display Force at Paris Auto Show
description: China’s ambitions to become a force in the European car market were on full display this week at the Paris Motor Show, where a record number of the country’s automakers unveiled cutting-edge electric models despite a recent European Union decision to impose anti-subsidy tariffs on their vehicles.

title: Hail, Salmon Caesar
description: Over here at New York Times Cooking, we’ve been rhapsodizing about fall lately: the apples, the soups, the stews, the roast chickens, the chill in the air, the sweater season of it all. But our readers are all over the United States and abroad, too, and it may not be your time to shrug on some fleece. It may, in fact, be pretty hot out where you are.

title: With $32 Billion in Aid, Native Americans Push Against History of Neglect
description: Cortez, a Colorado town of about 9,000 people tucked near the San Juan Mountains, has the trappings of a humble but healthy small-town economy: bustling businesses, congenial single-family homes, a park with grassy fields, a public pool, playgrounds, a pond and skate ramps.

title: The Latest Hot Item on Wedding Registries? A New House.
description: Push the blenders, cutlery sets and fine china aside.

title: Local Officials Cannot Refuse to Certify Election Results, Georgia Judge Rules
description: A county judge in Georgia has rejected an argument by allies of former President Donald J. Trump that local election officials have the power to refuse to certify election results, finding the process to be mandatory and one that must meet critical deadlines.

title: My Favorite Artwork | Lorna Simpson
description: The artist discusses a film she saw only once but that had a lasting influence on her work.

title: Trump Media Stock Surges, Nearly Tripling in Matter of Weeks
description: Over the past few weeks, former President Donald J. Trump has become a lot richer, and so have shareholders in the social media company that bears his name.

title: Clemente Bar Opens Above Eleven Madison Park With an Artistic Flourish
description: This highly anticipated bar and beyond, upstairs from Daniel Humm’s Eleven Madison Park, is a collaboration with the neo-expressionist artist Francesco Clemente. The artist aspired to have a drink named for him; Mr. Humm, who has many pals in the art world, responded with an entire cocktail lounge that Mr. Clemente decorated in situ. An abbreviated tasting menu ($225) at the counter is an option, as are vegan bar snacks like tempura fries and an agedashi tofu dog to accompany often elaborate drinks.

title: As Black Voters Hesitate on Harris, Democrats Race to Win Them Over
description: In Atlanta, a group of Black entertainers and elected officials took the stage at a brewery to urge a crowd of Black men to support Vice President Kamala Harris. In Milwaukee, dozens of volunteers fanned out across Black neighborhoods to encourage sometimes skeptical residents to vote. And in a blitz of national media interviews and campaign ads, Ms. Harris herself made her case to Black voters.

title: Could the Lone Fed Dissenter Be in Line for a Powerful Role if Trump Wins?
