title: Broadway Is Singing Louis Armstrong’s Songs. Here Are 6 Classics.
description: When Christopher Renshaw was growing up in England in the 1950s and ’60s, everybody knew about Louis Armstrong. “He was an icon for me as a child,” he said. “He was just there — he’s smiling, he’s funny.”

title: Free Electricity, Anyone? Britain Tries New Tricks to Green Its Grid.
description: Were Heathcliff to roam the blustery moors around Wuthering Heights today, he might be interrupted by a ping on his cellphone saying something like this: The wind is raging, so power is cheap. It’s a good time to plug in the car.

title: A Pivotal Choice: Trump vs. Harris on Climate Change
description: The window is closing for nations to reduce enough of the pollution that is heating the planet to avoid the most dangerous levels of climate change, according to scientists across the world. And the outcome of next week’s presidential election could determine whether the United States and other countries meet that challenge.

title: Japan Is Entering a New Era of Instability
description: The political dominance of Japan’s Liberal Democratic Party has been remarkable.

title: An Unlikely Winner in the Office Real Estate Slump? A Dance Troupe.
description: Likely you’ve heard about the proliferation of empty urban office space since the pandemic and the rise in remote and hybrid work. But if you’ve given any thought to who might fill some of that space, you’ve probably overlooked a promising group: dancers.

title: $1.75 Million Homes in California
description: This newly built four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house is in Tahoe Donner, a homeowners association in the town of Truckee where amenities include swimming pools, downhill and cross-country ski trails, and access to a private beach on Donner Lake. The property has its own trail linking it to the community’s trails. The bars and restaurants in downtown Truckee are 10 minutes away by car.

title: What Role Does Fear Play in Your Life?
description: It’s spooky season, a time of year when people lean into fears and frights with scary movies, haunted houses and gory costumes.

title: What Threats Does My Vote Really Face?
description: Follow your vote from the ballot box to the Electoral College to understand our election system and what obstacles might stand in its way.

title: Trump’s Changing Messages on Abortion, in 660 Quotes
description: Donald Trump has softened his rhetoric, contradicted himself and nearly dropped “pro-life” from his vocabulary. Yet there is no evidence that his views on abortion have changed.

title: Anita Hill: The Smearing of Kamala Harris
description: It’s not easy to remain calm and collected in the glare of intense public scrutiny, especially when the opposition is set on denying your integrity, competence and accomplishments. But call it grace, poise or dignity, Kamala Harris has managed to make a positive case for her candidacy every day since President Biden endorsed her to take his place on the Democratic ticket. Think about it: No presidential nominees in modern history have faced such a direct challenge to the authenticity of their identity and by extension their qualifications to be the president.

title: The Real Reasons the G.O.P. Is Spending Millions on Anti-Trans Ads
description: The Republican Party has been investing millions of dollars in anti-trans advertisements in a play to reach moderates and voters on the left who feel uncomfortable with or confused by transgender rights. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the New York Times Opinion deputy editor, Patrick Healy, and the columnist M. Gessen discuss these ads and the fear they’re tapping into in American society.

title: Inside the Movement Behind Trump’s Election Lies
description: For years, Republican activists have huddled in video meetings to talk about remaking democracy and plan for the election. The New York Times has obtained the recordings.

title: Inside a Pro-Trump Network Ready to Challenge the Election
description: For years, right-wing activists have huddled in video meetings to talk about how to remake democracy. They’ve spread conspiracy theories about illegal voting and planned meticulously for next week’s election. The New York Times has obtained the recordings. Alexandra Berzon, an investigative reporter covering American politics and elections for The New York Times, explains.

title: Clark Art Institute Receives ‘Princely’ Collection of European Treasures
description: Museums are lucky if they receive either a large collection of valuable artworks or a big check. Getting both at the same time is rare.

title: What Is the Perfect Length for a Winter Coat?
description: Of all the garments in a wardrobe, a coat may be the most fraught. Especially a winter coat.

title: Happy 120th Birthday, New York City Subway!
description: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a very important New York City institution that is 120 years old.

title: Democrats Won the Ad War. Will It Be Enough?
description: Here’s what we learned after analyzing 3.7 million election ads.

title: Michelle Obama: ‘I Am Asking You, From the Core of My Being, to Take Our Lives Seriously’
description: The following is excerpted from Mrs. Obama’s speech on Saturday at a Kamala Harris rally in Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: ‘Crazy’ Is Beginning to Sound Like an Understatement
description: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. We are a week out from the election. Kamala Harris said the other day that she thinks Donald Trump is a fascist. Do you agree?

title: State of the Race: National Polls Tighten With 8 Days to Go
description: Results and analysis of new polls in the Senate races in Texas and Nebraska are at the bottom of this article.

title: Republicans Cling to Slim Leads in Nebraska and Texas Senate Races
description: Dan Osborn, a union leader and political independent, is within striking distance of Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, while in Texas, Representative Colin Allred, a Democrat, has more ground to make up against Senator Ted Cruz, according to new polls from The New York Times and Siena College.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: ‘Sane-washing’
description: First of all, thank you for reading The Times and for the question, which I have heard from other readers during this election cycle.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Choosing which reporters cover which candidates
description: We have a mix of campaign-coverage veterans and fresh-eyed newcomers writing about the candidates in not only the presidential contest, but in other races across the country. Some of our political reporters bring decades of experience — like Adam Nagourney, who has covered 10 presidential elections — while others are on campaign trails for the first time in their careers.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: False claims about election integrity
description: We have several reporters focused on Trump’s false claims about the legitimacy of the 2020 election and false claims made during this campaign cycle, such as about Haitian immigrants eating pets — and their many consequences. First and foremost, we try to debunk any false claim as quickly as possible. But we also go much deeper, looking into the source, tracking how something spreads across social media and examining real-world consequences.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: When do we call races?
description: The Times will not call a race before all polls are scheduled to close in a state. A claim of victory — or a concession — by a candidate is not the same as a race call.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Polling and 2016
description: The 2016 polls have, understandably, left a lot of people feeling anxious about the performance of the polls this time around. Interestingly, in 2016 the national polls were actually fairly accurate, but polls in key states underestimated Donald Trump’s support by a wide margin. Pollsters did correct for those errors by accounting for the fact that voters were increasingly polarized by education. (More non-college-educated voters were moving toward Republicans, and polls were not adjusting by education level to account for that.) But then in 2020, polling again had a big miss, and this time the reasons were less clear. It could have been that the coronavirus pandemic scrambled the ways in which people voted, or that there was record turnout that year.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Choosing the top story
description: Reporters are responsible only for covering the stories they are assigned or the candidates whose campaigns they follow. They don’t get a say in where their stories run, or how their stories are displayed. Neither do their immediate editors, whose sole responsibility is to edit stories for content, style and grammar.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,228
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 506
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: A Final Week of Campaigning, and Measured Words After Airstrikes on Iran
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: The Trump Campaign’s Big Gamble
description: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

title: Duterte Says He Takes ‘Full Legal Responsibility’ for Philippine Drug War
description: The former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte defended his so-called war on drugs in testimony before the country’s Senate on Monday, saying he took “full legal responsibility” for the campaign of extrajudicial killings that left thousands dead and is being investigated by the International Criminal Court.

title: Scott Durkin, C.E.O. of Douglas Elliman Realty, Fired Amid Company Turmoil
description: The president and chief executive of the Douglas Elliman brokerage has been terminated, less than a week after the sudden retirement of Howard Lorber, the parent company’s chief executive officer.

title: The 2024 Stakes on Health Care
description: After several elections with health care at the forefront, the issue has faded into the background this cycle. But the stakes are still high.

title: Meloni Battles Judges in Italy Over Her Anti-Migrant Plan
description: Italy’s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, had scored a coup. She pushed through a tough anti-migration plan that would force some asylum seekers headed for Italy instead into a detention center in Albania while their claims are heard. At a time when anti-immigration sentiments are rising in Europe, the program caught the eyes of other European leaders who viewed it as a potential blueprint.

title: New Horror for Readers Who Want to Be Completely Terrified
description: The town at the center of Yvonne Battle-Felton’s new novel, CURDLE CREEK (Holt, 292 pp., $27.99), is a small, all-Black, separatist community with a strict population policy: “One in, one out.” To keep the enclave safe, there are many yearly rituals required of residents, including Moving On, Warding Off, the Calling and the Running of the Widows.

title: A Seismic Election Sends Asia’s Most Stable Democracy Into Chaos
description: For years, Japan has managed to resist the populist waves that have swept Europe and the United States as disaffected electorates have demanded radical change.

title: What Japan’s Political Uncertainty Means for Its Market Rally
description: The steady course of the Japanese economy and business environment that has helped attract a torrent of investment in the past two years could be undercut by the political turmoil resulting from the country’s parliamentary elections on Sunday.

title: Democrats Use Gas Station Kiosks to Say Trump Will Make Life More Expensive
description: Americans bagging up their purchases at hundreds of gas stations and convenience stores across the Midwest will hear a message from Democrats that former President Donald J. Trump’s policies will increase the price of fuel and add thousands of dollars to the cost of raising a family.

title: Corporate America Hedges on Trump 2.0
description: As the presidential race nears its end next week, the most notable public sound from many C.E.O.s and businesses on the election has been silence — and Donald Trump’s camp is increasingly interpreting that as a sign that corporate America may be preparing for him to win.

title: Tommy Robinson, Anti-Immigrant Agitator in Britain, Sentenced to Jail
description: Tommy Robinson, Britain’s best-known far-right and anti-immigrant agitator, was sentenced on Monday to 18 months in prison for defying a court order by repeating false claims about a teenage Syrian refugee who had successfully sued him for libel.

title: Israeli Forces Withdraw From Northern Gaza Hospital After 3-Day Raid
description: The Israeli military said on Monday that its forces had withdrawn from a hospital in the northern Gaza Strip after a three-day raid during which Palestinian health officials said nearly all of the medical workers at the complex were detained and two children died.

title: Ukraine Braces for Russians to Assault With North Korean Troops
description: The United States warned on Monday that North Korean soldiers were moving toward Russia’s western Kursk region, which Ukraine invaded in August, as Ukrainian forces braced for what they said could be imminent assaults involving the new troops.

title: This Three-Ingredient Fish Dish Is Minimalist Magic
description: Who isn’t stirred by the ease and brevity of a three-ingredient recipe? Minimalist dishes are kitchen haikus — short, focused compositions that get right to the essence of their ingredients.

title: How Are the World’s Trees Doing? A New Assessment Has Answers.
description: More than a third of the world’s tree species are threatened with extinction, according to the first comprehensive assessment of trees by the world’s leading scientific authority on the status of species.

title: Boeing Will Sell $19 Billion in Stock as Strike Weighs on Finances
description: Boeing on Monday began to raise roughly $19 billion by selling stock, an attempt to shore up its finances as a costly and disruptive worker strike weighs on the plane maker’s balance sheet.

title: Paul Morrissey, Andy Warhol’s Cinematic Collaborator, Dies at 86
description: Paul Morrissey, whose loose cinéma-vérité films made with Andy Warhol in the late 1960s and early ’70s captured New York’s demimonde of drug addicts, drag queens and hipsters and turned an unlikely stable of amateur actors into underground stars, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: As Gaza Talks Resume, Little Progress Is Expected Before the U.S. Election
description: As the Biden administration makes a final diplomatic push in the Middle East before next week’s U.S. presidential election, little is expected to be achieved before the result is known, officials and analysts in the region said on Monday.

title: The Rebellious Scientist Who Made Kamala Harris
description: On her first day of work, the young bioengineering major climbed down the basement steps of a cancer laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., and caught sight of someone summarily beheading a mouse.

title: How Well Do You Know Classic Books for Halloween Reading?
description: Magic, madness and supernatural horror have driven many book plots over the centuries. This short quiz scares up several popular novels to test your knowledge.

title: That’s a Lot of Cheddar: Scammers Steal $390,000 of British Cheese
description: It’s been called “the grate cheese robbery.”

title: Wages Have Outpaced Inflation. But Not for Everyone.
description: Have Americans’ paychecks kept up with the cost of living over the past several years?

title: Corrections: Oct. 28, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Timothée Chalamet Showed Up at His Own Look-Alike Contest
description: It was a bit of fun in Washington Square Park: a contest to see who looked the most like the actor and heartthrob Timothée Chalamet.

title: 5 Eerie Games to Haunt During Halloween Week
description: You’re utterly alone. Blood drips onto snow. A fanged entity slashes your significant other. A monstrous chase ends in death. Just in time for Halloween, five affecting horror games are full of harrowing alienation and loneliness.

title: Trump’s Vast Tariffs Would Rock Global Businesses and Shake Alliances
description: At a rally in Latrobe, Pa., earlier this month, former President Donald J. Trump paused in front of a crowd holding signs that read “Save Our Steel” to pay homage to one of his favorite concepts.

title: Bloomberg, After Months of Pressure, Donates $50 Million to Help Harris
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, under extraordinary pressure from friends and fellow billionaires to do more to help Vice President Kamala Harris, recently donated about $50 million to a nonprofit organization that is supporting her presidential run, according to four people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Why a Key Biden Effort to Boost Affordable Housing Has Faced Hurdles
description: When company officials at Resia, a multifamily housing developer based in South Florida, first heard about a new Biden administration effort to provide low-interest loans for housing projects near transit stations, they thought it was a “very attractive opportunity.”

title: Timothée Chalamet Crashes Look-alike Contest
description: The Oscar-nominated actor showed up unannounced to a look-alike contest for himself in New York City.

title: The Presidential Endorsements That Weren’t
description: To the Editor:

title: MAGA Unchained in Madison Square Garden
description: Donald Trump’s MAGA Lollapalooza at Madison Square Garden on Sunday began with an iconic scene from the 1970 biopic “Patton” on the jumbotron. Strutting in front of a giant American flag, George C. Scott, playing the legendary World War II general, growled, of the Nazis, “We’re not just going to shoot the bastards. We’re going to cut out their living guts and use them to grease the treads of our tanks.” While it was nice, I suppose, to hear anti-Hitler rhetoric at a Trump rally, the belligerent talk of total war was unnerving in the context of a campaign focused on crushing internal enemies.

title: Volkswagen May Close German Plants for First Time in Its History
description: Volkswagen could shut down as many as three factories in Germany and lay off tens of thousands of workers as it seeks to regain its edge in Europe amid slumping sales and increased competition from China, the company’s top employee representative said Monday.

title: ‘Lady Blogs’ Would Have Had a Field Day With This Election
description: It was 2016, and the future was female.

title: Investigators Identify ‘Suspect Vehicle’ in Ballot Drop Box Fires in the Pacific Northwest
description: Two ballot drop boxes in the Pacific Northwest were set ablaze in apparent cases of arson in the early morning hours on Monday, and elections officials at one site said they feared that hundreds of ballots had been destroyed.

title: The Misogynistic, Bigoted and Crude Rally Remarks Trump Hasn’t Disavowed
description: By the time former President Donald J. Trump took the stage at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, a parade of speakers had already spent hours disparaging Latinos, Black people, Palestinians and Jews; directing misogynistic comments at Vice President Kamala Harris; and echoing language used by the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Recruiting Gen Z Voters With ‘Poll Dancers’ and Yung Gravy
description: The rapper Yung Gravy has a pitch for young people who may be on the fence about voting.

title: Jon Stewart Extends ‘Daily Show’ Run Through 2025
description: Jon Stewart is sticking around. After nearly nine months with Stewart back at the desk of “The Daily Show,” Comedy Central announced on Monday that he would continue to host the show on Monday nights through 2025.

title: Whether Harris or Trump Wins, Seeking Asylum in the U.S. May Never Be the Same
description: For decades, granting political asylum has been part of the story that the United States has told about itself. As a Western democracy and a nation of immigrants, that national ethos goes, America has an obligation to offer safe harbor to people fleeing persecution in their home countries.

title: Adam Schiff, Not Yet a Senator, Deploys to Bolster Potential Future Colleagues
description: On Friday night, Steve Garvey, the former Major League Baseball star and current Republican candidate for Senate in California, was at Dodger Stadium cheering on the home team as it faced off against the New York Yankees in this first game of the World Series.

title: He Was 5 When Border Agents Took Him From His Father. He Hasn’t Forgotten.
description: For José and his family, the moment still feels raw, all these years later.

title: Harris Campaign Distances Itself From Biden in the Crucial Final Days
description: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

title: Harris Aides Quietly Grow More Bullish on Defeating Trump
description: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

title: Gérard Depardieu’s Sexual Assault Trial in France Is Postponed Until March
description: For years, accusations of groping, sexual harassment and sexual assault have been made against the French movie star Gérard Depardieu — all of which he has denied.

title: Israel’s Parliament Opens With Passage of Bill Banning U.N. Agency
description: Israel’s Knesset opened its winter session on Monday by passing bills that could threaten the work of the main U.N. agency that assists Palestinians, UNRWA.

title: Who Is Tony Hinchcliffe, the Trump Rally Comedian?
description: The stand-up comedian Tony Hinchcliffe took the stage early in former President Donald J. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, hurling a wave of insults and vulgar statements at minority groups including Jews, Latinos and African Americans.

title: Man Who Made Violent Threats Skirted Arrest and Then Shot a Neighbor
description: A man in Minneapolis hit a neighbor with a stick and threatened others with a knife and a gun, according to court records, and though warrants were issued, the police never arrested him. Then he shot a neighbor.

title: Where to Travel This Winter, Whether You Want Sun or Snow
description: Planning a vacation for the week between Christmas and New Years can feel anything but festive. Hotel and rental rates are generally at their peak, many properties require weeklong or 10-night minimums and rooms book up fast. But below are 15 great hotels in enticing destinations that — at press time — still have openings for at least a few days between Dec. 21 and Jan. 1 and, while minimum stays vary widely during that period, many of the places included here don’t insist on more than a two- or three-night stay. (The rates listed below are for Christmas week.) Better still, use this list as inspiration for a getaway in January, February or early spring and enjoy the perks of shoulder season: lower prices and fewer tourists.

title: Man Gets Life Without Parole in Kidnapping and Murder of Memphis Teacher
description: A Tennessee man who kidnapped and killed a teacher in September 2022 was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without parole after pleading guilty in an arrangement that spared him from a possible death sentence.

title: It Shouldn’t Be This Easy to Sign Away Your Right to a Trial
description: A century ago, arbitration was a hot item. President Calvin Coolidge signed the Federal Arbitration Act on Feb. 12, 1925. It recognized private dispute resolution as a valid alternative to trials, and the arbitrator’s decisions in such disputes as binding, albeit subject to limited judicial review.

title: John F. Keenan, U.S. Judge in Myerson and Marcos Trials, Dies at 94
description: John F. Keenan, a longtime federal judge in Manhattan who presided over the high-profile trials of Bess Myerson, a popular former cultural-affairs commissioner in New York City and ex-beauty queen, and Imelda Marcos, the extravagant former first lady of the Philippines, died on Sunday at his home in the Bronx. He was 94.

title: Waymo Raises $5.6 Billion From Outside Investors
description: Amid its push to grow its fleet of autonomous robot taxis and expand into new cities, Waymo has raised $5.6 billion from outside investors, its largest funding round to date.

title: ‘Dahomey’ Celebrated Looted Art’s Return. What Happened Next?
description: Throughout the movie “Dahomey,” the eerie voice of a 19th century West African king emerges from the depths of history.

title: Jeff Bezos Defends Decision to End Washington Post Endorsements
description: Jeff Bezos, the billionaire owner of The Washington Post, whose decision to end presidential endorsements at the paper set off a firestorm inside and outside the paper last week, said on Monday in his first comments about the change that it had been done to improve the newsroom’s credibility, not to protect his own personal interests.

title: Bannon’s Release From Prison Will Unleash an Agitator Into a Heated Campaign
description: When Stephen K. Bannon reported to federal prison almost four months ago, he left his podcast in the hands of lesser-known pundits and a void in the right-wing messaging machine behind Donald J. Trump.

title: Biden Waits in Line and Casts His Vote for Harris
description: With eight days to Nov. 5, President Biden on Monday stood in line with more than a hundred early voters in Delaware and cast his ballot for Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: In Montana, Republican Tim Sheehy Tries to Outrun Jon Tester, and Scrutiny
description: Tim Sheehy, the novice Republican candidate in perhaps the most important Senate race in the country, was not downplaying his lack of a political pedigree when he stepped in front of a welcoming audience at the American Legion hall in downtown Big Timber, Mont.

title: Harris Ties Trump to the Fatal Fallout of Abortion Bans
description: Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign has been running this 60-second ad on television stations in Georgia this month, and has spent $348,367 on it since it first aired on Oct. 16, according to AdImpact.

title: British Labour Lawmaker Suspended After Punches Thrown
description: A British lawmaker was suspended by the governing Labour Party on Monday, after video appeared to show him punching a man in the face, knocking him down, and then repeatedly hitting him as he was lying in the street.

title: Philadelphia District Attorney Sues Musk Over $1 Million Voter Giveaways
description: District Attorney Larry Krasner of Philadelphia filed a lawsuit on Monday to stop Elon Musk and his Trump-supporting organization, America PAC, from continuing their $1 million daily giveaway in Pennsylvania, calling it an illegal lottery scheme to influence voters in the presidential election.

title: Republicans Distance Themselves From Puerto Rico Insult at Trump’s Rally
description: Republicans moved quickly to distance themselves from remarks disparaging Puerto Rico made on Sunday by a comedian at the Madison Square Garden rally for Donald J. Trump, a reflection of growing party concern that fallout from the event could hurt Mr. Trump with a critical voting constituency in the final days of this campaign.

title: The Cookies You Want to Bake on Election Day
description: Ahead of the 2020 presidential election, interest in election cake resurfaced from its heyday more than 200 years ago. While mentions of the cake predate the American Revolution, the first-known published recipe is in the 1796 book “American Cookery” by Amelia Simmons. That yeast-risen butter cake called for a pint of wine and quart of brandy, which sounds pretty great.

title: Trump Hints at ‘Little Secret’ With House Republicans, Setting Off a Panic
description: Speaker Mike Johnson was taking in former President Donald J. Trump’s grievance-fueled closing rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon when the main actor onstage turned to him and drew him into the drama.

title: Trump Team Fears Damage From Racist Rally Remarks
description: Donald J. Trump and his allies are full of bravado over his chances of victory in the closing days of the 2024 campaign. But there are signs, publicly and privately, that the former president and his team are worried that their opponents’ descriptions of him as a racist and a fascist may be breaking through to segments of voters.

title: Tuesday Briefing: The U.S. Campaign’s Final Stretch
description: With one week to go until Election Day, Kamala Harris is centering her closing argument on the stakes of another Trump presidency. Donald Trump held a provocative closing rally in New York City.

title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Resume, but Are Overshadowed by U.S. Election
description: As international negotiators discussed a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip on Monday, officials and analysts said there was little expectation that Israel and Hamas would agree to a truce before the American presidential election next Tuesday.

title: N.Y.P.D. Chief Stirs Criticism With Newsmax Appearance at Trump Rally
description: A high-ranking New York City police chief drew criticism after appearing on a conservative news channel in full uniform at Donald J. Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally, with detractors saying he seemed to lend support to the Republican presidential nominee.

title: Iran Executes German-Iranian Opponent Who Lived in U.S.
description: Iran on Monday executed an Iranian-born opponent of the government who had German citizenship and lived in the United States, the country’s judiciary announced, four years after Iranian agents abducted him in Dubai, according to members of his family.

title: How Bad Are Gas Stoves for My Health?
description: However much you may love cooking on your gas stove, it’s bad for your health.

title: U.S. Officials Sweep Troubled Brooklyn Prison Where 2 Were Killed
description: The U.S. Department of Justice and other law enforcement agencies on Monday morning conducted a sweep of a dangerous federal prison in Brooklyn where two detainees were fatally stabbed this summer.

title: Musk Repeatedly Raises the Idea That Harris, or He, Could Be Assassinated
description: In speeches to pro-Trump voters across Pennsylvania, Elon Musk has repeated a line he uses about the assassination of Vice President Kamala Harris — saying it would be pointless because she is a “puppet” of unnamed Washington power brokers.

title: Steve Mariotti, Whose Trauma Led Him to Help Youths at Risk, Dies at 71
description: Steve Mariotti, a teacher in some of New York’s roughest schools who discovered that his bored, disrespectful students suddenly tuned in when he talked about running a business, inspiring him to create an organization that has taught business skills to more than 1 million at-risk youths in the U.S. and abroad, died on Oct. 20 in Union City, N.J. He was 71.

title: Rally Backlash Puts Trump on the Defensive
description: Donald Trump and his allies are full of bravado over his chances of victory in November. But there are signs that the former president and his team are worried that their opponents’ descriptions of him as a racist and a fascist may be breaking through to segments of voters.

title: A Caller Told 911 a Bear Had Chased Him Off a Cliff. The Police Say It Was Murder.
description: The 911 caller in rural Tennessee told a dispatcher on Oct. 18 that he had been injured when a bear chased him off a cliff and into water. But when emergency workers arrived, the authorities said, they found something entirely different.

title: Michelle Obama Decries a ‘Double Standard’ in Treatment of Trump and Harris
description: For three months, as Vice President Kamala Harris has pressed her case for the White House, some voters have insisted they just don’t know enough about her. Pundits have grumbled that she is light on specifics; journalists have lamented that she wasn’t doing more interviews, or answering tougher questions, or answering easy questions more crisply. Her opponents have cast her as an “empty suit,” a lightweight with dangerous ideas.

title: Latinos Blast Disparaging Remarks Made at Trump’s N.Y.C. Rally
description: Latinos warned that the racist and vulgar insults made by some speakers at Donald J. Trump’s rally in New York City — particularly those by a stand-up comic — could cost the former president votes this election.

title: Louisiana State Trooper Avoids Jail in Death of Ronald Greene
description: A former Louisiana state trooper who had faced felony charges in the 2019 death of a Black man who was beaten while in police custody pleaded no contest to significantly reduced charges on Monday, allowing him to avoid jail time in a case that drew protests and spurred a federal civil rights investigation.

title: Woman Charged With Hate Crime in Pepper-Spraying of Muslim Uber Driver
description: Shohel Mahmud had no obvious reason to worry when he picked up two young women who had ordered an Uber around midnight on July 31.

title: Trump’s Biggest Con: Pretending He’s on the Side of Working Men and Women
description: Donald Trump has always been a con man. As a businessman, he left behind a trail of investors who lost money in failed ventures even as he profited, students who paid thousands for worthless courses, unpaid contractors and more. Even amid his current presidential campaign he has been hawking overpriced gold sneakers and Trump Bibles printed in China.

title: Trump Repeatedly Refers to CNN’s Anderson Cooper as ‘Allison’
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has spent the past several days calling the CNN host Anderson Cooper by a woman’s name, as he devotes much of the final stretch of a close presidential campaign to increasingly unfiltered displays of grievance and bigotry.

title: Israel’s Parliament Passes Bills Banning Agency That Aids Palestinians
description: Israel’s Parliament passed two laws on Monday that could threaten the work of UNRWA, the main U.N. agency that aids Palestinians, by barring its operations in the country. In doing so, Israel defied calls from the Biden administration, which has warned that the legislation could prompt an even greater humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

title: Obama Is the Same. His Coalition Isn’t.
description: Tony Jones, 58, a truck driver and a member of the Teamsters union, drove from his home in rural Maybee, Mich., to see former President Barack Obama campaign for Vice President Kamala Harris last week in Detroit.

title: Why Trump Uses Comics Like Tony Hinchcliffe to Spread His Message
description: The stand-up of Tony Hinchcliffe, a popular insult comic, became an immediate issue in the presidential campaign on Sunday after his racist lines at a Donald J. Trump rally earned immediate blowback and criticism from, among others, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Tim Walz.

title: Doug Emhoff Condemns Antisemitism as Democrats Court Jewish Voters
description: Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish second spouse, warned on Monday that another term for former President Donald J. Trump would gravely threaten American Jews, as he also vouched for Ms. Harris’s commitment to a community on edge over rising antisemitism.

title: ‘Bob’s Burgers’ Actor Sentenced to One Year in Prison for Role in Jan. 6 Riot
description: Jay Johnston, a comedian and actor who voiced Jimmy Pesto Sr. on the Fox sitcom “Bob’s Burgers,” was sentenced to a year and a day in prison over his involvement in the attack on the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

title: ‘Bad Kreyòl’ Review: Dueling Cultural Identities Make for a Weighty Comedy
description: Concluding a four-show run as one of Signature Theater’s writers-in-residence, Dominique Morisseau looks beyond her usual American petri dish in the comic and contemplative “Bad Kreyòl.” It’s the second world premiere of her seven-year tenure (stretched from five because of the Covid pandemic) with the company, which has staged her explorations of 1940s jazz (“Paradise Blue”), campus race relations and slavery (“Confederates”) and the aftershocks of revolutionary movements (“Sunset Baby”).

title: Puerto Ricans in Philadelphia Are Angered by Bigoted Remarks at Trump Rally
description: Puerto Rican residents of Philadelphia reacted with shock and anger on Monday at racist remarks against Puerto Rico and Latinos made by a speaker at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, joining a growing public backlash.

title: Secret Files in Election Case Show How Judges Limited Trump’s Privilege
description: Court documents unsealed on Monday shed new light on a legal battle over which of former President Donald J. Trump’s White House aides had to testify before a grand jury in Washington that charged him with plotting to overturn the 2020 election, showing how judges carved out limits on executive privilege.

title: Harris Dives Into a Frenetic Final Week With a Swing Through Michigan
description: Vice President Kamala Harris raced across Michigan on Monday, making three stops in the battleground state to begin a furious final week of her presidential campaign.

title: Trump Long Ago Crossed the Line From Propriety to Profanity. Then Came the Garden.
description: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

title: Corrections: Oct. 29, 2024
description: A news analysis article on Sunday about the route Iran could go following the Israeli strikes on Saturday, overstated what is known about the current health of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. He was said to have been seriously ill in 2022; there have been no recent reports about his health.

title: Ford Foundation Gives $10 Million to Studio Museum in Harlem
description: The Ford Foundation has awarded the Studio Museum in Harlem a grant of $10 million to endow its director and chief curator, a position held for the last 20 years by Thelma Golden.

title: Trump Attacks Michelle Obama, Days After She Criticized Him
description: Former President Donald J. Trump said that Michelle Obama had made a “big mistake” by criticizing him, as he responded on Monday for the first time to her recent searing comments about his mental state.

title: Repeat Word for Word
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance
description: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance

title: No, poll workers aren’t handing out Sharpies to invalidate ballots.
description: Some people have falsely claimed that election workers have provided Sharpies, markers or other writing utensils to certain voters in an attempt to somehow invalidate their ballots.

title: No, noncitizens are not voting in droves.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump and his allies have falsely claimed that scores of noncitizens — including illegal immigrants — are voting or trying to vote in the United States presidential elections.

title: Quote of the Day: Village So Spooky, Even Skeptics Get the Jitters
description: “I didn’t smell anything, I didn’t see anything, I just felt something.”

title: How Russia, China and Iran Are Interfering in the Presidential Election
description: When Russia interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, spreading divisive and inflammatory posts online to stoke outrage, its posts were brash and riddled with spelling errors and strange syntax. They were designed to get attention by any means necessary.

title: Arrests and Spying Charges Alarm Diplomats and Aid Workers in Yemen
description: Friends and former colleagues of Shaif al-Hamdani did not know if they would ever see him again.

title: Part-Time Farmers, Part-Time Rock Stars: A Chinese Band’s Unlikely Rise
description: Before setting out on his band’s first national tour, before recording another album and before appearing on a major television network, Ba Nong had one task: finishing the summer harvest.

title: The New Threat to Brazil’s Forests: Chemicals
description: Brazil’s satellites did not detect anything alarming. Yet down on the ground, the trees were dying.

title: After Shaky Start for Labour, First Budget Brings Chance for Reset
description: Two years ago, a British government rolled out a fiscal plan that rattled financial markets, drove up mortgage rates, torpedoed the pound and doomed the prime minister, Liz Truss, who would later resign after less than two months in office.

title: Puerto Rico’s G.O.P. Chairman Demands Apology From Trump for Comic’s Remarks
description: Puerto Rico’s Republican Party chairman said on Monday that he would withhold his support from former President Donald J. Trump unless he apologized for racist remarks that an insult comic made about the U.S. territory on Sunday during Mr. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden.

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: In the closing days of the 2024 campaign, Donald Trump and his allies have sought to tamp down criticism of inflammatory, racist remarks by speakers at a Trump rally at Madison Square Garden in New York City, including a comedian’s reference to Puerto Rico as “a floating island of garbage.”

title: Why Trump Has an Edge With These 11 Michigan Voters — Even Though They Don’t Like Him
description: The group participants discuss the state of the race and what may drive them toward a given candidate.

title: Word of the Day: pagoda
description: The word pagoda has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 5 in “An Architect Who Builds Community Wins the Pritzker Prize” by Robin Pogrebin:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Fake Blood Isn’t Cheap: Why It Costs $45 to Enter This Haunted House
description: It’s not as if Blood Manor can just transform into an office after Halloween.

title: What Ants and Orcas Can Teach Us About Death
description: In the summer of 2018, off the coast of British Columbia, an orca named Tahlequah gave birth. When the calf died after just half an hour, Tahlequah refused to let go. For more than two weeks, she carried her calf’s body around, often balancing it on her nose as she swam.

title: A House Divided
description: Do your family and friends hold similar political views — especially on which presidential candidate they believe would best serve the country?

title: What Giuliani Is Losing: The Co-op. The Yankees Swag. The Convertible.
description: The items read like a treasure trove of riches for New York royalty.

title: A Modest Monument to the Dodgers’ Days in Brooklyn
description: Every now and then, someone will wander into the parking lot of the sprawling apartment complex in Brooklyn where Ezra Askotzky works and start staring inquisitively at the ground.

title: Jon Stewart Fears Madison Square Garden Will Never Be the Same
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Stepping Into a Hidden World in the Everglades
description: Deep within the seemingly endless saw-grass marshes of the Florida Everglades, I found myself standing on an unexpected speck of dry land on a bright spring day. The boat ride to this spot had fully exposed my tour group to the blustery wind and midday sun, and the island, by contrast, felt lush and welcoming, ringed by trees that cast shadows and tempered the gusts and insulated us from the elements beyond.

title: These Are the Weirdest Houses We’ve Ever Covered
description: For a pair of avant-garde artists, immortality wasn’t just a dream — it was a possibility. As long, that is, as you were committed to an uncomfortable existence.

title: Extra Extra!The End Times, Onscreen
description: Alien invasions, viruses, zombies, meteors, natural or human-caused catastrophes. When the end is nigh in apocalyptic, dystopian, disaster or horror films and television shows, there is often a distinct moment that offers audiences a glimpse of what was known in those last days before civilization was forever changed: the front pages of newspapers.

title: What Should I Eat While Taking Antibiotics?
description: Q: I was recently prescribed antibiotics and I’m worried that it might kill the “good” bacteria in my gut. What can I do to minimize the damage?

title: How Will Harris Make a Last Plea to Voters? Here Are Clues From the Courtroom.
description: Vice President Kamala Harris gave a speech on Tuesday in Washington that she billed as the closing argument of her presidential campaign.

title: E.P.A., Just Rebounding From Trump Years, Faces an Uncertain Future
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has largely recovered from many of the staff exits and budget cuts that occurred during the Trump administration and, in some ways, has swiftly rebounded.

title: Taking on Nora Ephron, Movie by Movie and Book by Book
description: Late afternoon was still too early to have what Nora Ephron would have been having when she went out to dinner at Cafe Luxembourg, on Manhattan’s Upper West Side: the pan-seared lamb chops, served with some off-menu mint jelly the brasserie kept in a jar in the kitchen especially for her.

title: How Election Coverage Extends Beyond Politics
description: Election Day is seven days away. Every day of the countdown,  Times Insider will share an article about how our election coverage works. Today, journalists from across the newsroom discuss how the political conversation affects their beat.

title: The 25 Best Pizza Places in New York Right Now
description: If you were to dig deep below New York City’s streets, past the subway tunnels, you might expect to find thick layers of schist, gneiss and marble. But what you’d actually find is pizza, the cultural and emotional bedrock of a city that can’t even coalesce around a single baseball team. Here, finding a decent slice is as easy as jaywalking. But finding a great slice, one that’s worth eating down to that last bite of crust, is much harder.

title: Florida Stopped Being a Swing State Slowly, Then All at Once
description: Florida’s days as a presidential battleground are bygone. No longer do candidates drop in every few days during campaign season. No longer do voters get bombarded with their ads. Nor is there more than a whisper of doubt that the state will vote Republican.

title: Trump Says the Country Is ‘Dying.’ The Data Says Otherwise.
description: Narratives of national decline have intensified in recent years. Most prominent, of course, is Donald Trump’s vow to “make America great again,” in response to what he has called “a nation that is dying.” But there is also doomsaying on the far left, which sees a “late-stage capitalist hellscape” (to quote the journalist Taylor Lorenz) and is often resigned to voting in protest for a long-shot candidate or sitting out the election altogether.

title: I’ve Been Through a Lot of Election Nights. Here’s How Nov. 5 May Go.
description: Get ready for a long election night — or nights.

title: A Dying Artist Left His Legacy to MoMA. Today He’s Almost Forgotten.
description: When the artist Scott Burton decided on his deathbed to leave his estate to the Museum of Modern Art in 1989, he thought he was securing a permanent place in art history books. Instead, the decision made him a mere footnote — almost invisible.

title: Elon Musk Wants Big Families. He Bought a Secret Compound for His.
description: On a quiet, leafy street of multimillion-dollar properties, one stands out: a 14,400-square-foot mansion that looks like a villa plucked from the hills of Tuscany and transplanted to Austin, Texas.

title: The Game Theory of Democracy
description: Adam Przeworski, a political scientist, left his native Poland a few months before the 1968 Prague Spring uprising and found he could not return home. To avoid being arrested as a dissident by the Communist government, he accepted a job abroad at a university in Santiago, Chile — only to watch his adopted country collapse into autocracy a few years later. In 1973, a violent coup installed a military dictatorship, led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, wiping out Chilean democracy in one brutal stroke. “Nobody expected that it would be as bloody as it was,” Przeworski told me. “Or that it would last for 17 years.”

title: Climate Change Should Make You Rethink Homeownership
description: As the Southeast begins to recover from back-to-back hurricanes, potential home buyers across the country should take notice of the billions of dollars in property damage from the storms, some of it uninsured. The tremendous loss in places such as Swannanoa, N.C., and Keaton Beach, Fla., shows that homeownership in a world of growing disaster risk is less of an asset than it once was.

title: For This Goth, Halloween Is Her Christmas
description: “October is my favorite month,” said the writer Tish Weinstock, who was sitting on a bench in the cemetery of Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan staring out at the grave of Alexander Hamilton.

title: What We Learned From Democrats’ Ads for Senate
description: What’s the strategy of Democrats in U.S. Senate races in red and purple states? David Leonhardt, a senior writer at The New York Times who runs The Morning daily newsletter, looks at their ads.

title: How Protest Pins Taught Me About My Family History
description: Five years ago, at my grandfather’s 98th birthday party, someone asked him to share the secret of longevity. He still had the energy of a man half his age. “The ultimate thing,” he said to the family and friends gathered around his cake, “is engaging in the social struggle of the moment. If you want to live a fulfilled life, you have to make sure the world survives.” Beside him, my grandmother nodded.

title: He Knows What Men Want (to Buy)
description: All was going as Chris Green had hoped.

title: At 200, Bruckner Is More Popular Than Ever With Conductors. Why?
description: Bruckner, Bruckner, everywhere.

title: In a Decisive Election, a Jewish Group Focuses on Climate Voters
description: Last week, dozens of Jewish volunteers gathered on a Zoom call to prepare to call voters for a get-out-the vote campaign called Chutzpah 2024.

title: Migrants in New York Have Become a Campaign Trope
description: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at how the migrant crisis in New York City became a campaign issue that candidates from both sides of the aisle in the state are using to attract voters.

title: Why This Senate Candidate Is a Potential ‘Shock to the System’
description: Much of the country is laser focused on the presidential election, but control of the Senate is also up for grabs in November. One of the seats in contention is, surprisingly, in deep-red Nebraska, where the independent Dan Osborn is running against the Trump-endorsed Republican Deb Fischer. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the columnist Michelle Goldberg travels to Nebraska to report on Osborn’s appeal and argues that his decision to run lays the groundwork for a “potential new avenue for a left-wing style of populist politics.”

title: Who Do You Hope Will Win the 2024 Presidential Election?
description: Please keep in mind that this forum is for teenagers only. While there are many places on NYTimes.com for adults to comment, this is the only dedicated spot for the voices of young people.

title: My Fellow Republicans, It’s Time to Say Enough With Trump
description: We Americans live in faith with our Constitution and with the past generations of Americans who swore to protect it and fought to defend it. One week from today, we will decide whether Donald Trump is fit to be president of the United States again. He is not. When we entrusted our Constitution and our democracy to him before, he betrayed us. Campaigning for the presidency again, he now promises to exact vengeance against his fellow Americans whom he deems “the enemy from within,” those who have dared to challenge his betrayal, an enemies list that includes Republicans and Democrats alike.

title: Inside Trump’s Truth Social Conspiracy Theory Machine
description: An analysis of thousands of Donald Trump’s Truth Social posts reveals that the former president directly promoted false conspiracy theories in at least 330 instances and amplified at least 145 conspiracists.

title: Trump Uses Thumbs-Up Video From Sept. 11 Event for a Snapchat Ad
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has released ads on the popular social media platform Snapchat for the first time in this year’s election — and one of them features him flashing a thumbs-up at a memorial for the nearly 3,000 victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance
description: In 2020 very few people had heard the name Vivek Ramaswamy. That was before he ran for president as a not-that-well-known biotech executive and anti-woke crusader, before he was one of the breakout stars of the Republican primaries, a guy who proved to be a lot faster on his feet at a debate and in front of a crowd than a lot of the much more experienced politicians who were competing against him.

title: Trump Is Less Confident Than He Says. His Rally at Madison Square Garden Proves It.
description: Donald Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night was supposed to be the capstone event of his campaign, a triumphant celebration of authoritarian strength. With millions watching, he would march into the final week of the contest as a conquering champion, so popular he could fill an arena in deep-blue New York twice over.

title: An Apartment in the Center of Paris, Inspired by Venice
description: When Nathan Litera and Lyatt Samama began looking for a new home in the heart of Paris, they needed a place that would serve as more than just as a residence. The couple also wanted something that would double as a showroom for their interior design firm, where they could put the full breadth of their talents on display.

title: An Ethical Minefield Awaits a Possible Second Trump Presidency
description: Days before Donald J. Trump became president in 2017, he promised to rein in his company’s freewheeling ways, assuring the American people that his family business would not “take advantage of” his presidency.

title: Halloween TV, Where Things Are Even Worse
description: This selection of shows from October’s annual parade of horror series will take you on a tour of places where the world appears to be out of control: a South Korea going through a religious frenzy, a Georgia farm under attack, a bucolic English village visited by aliens, a Japanese seaside town haunted by spirals. Just keep telling yourself it’s fiction.

title: We’ve Just Had a Glimpse of the World to Come
description: Last week at a lavish global summit in the Russian city of Kazan, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia, once a darling of the West — winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and formerly a staunch ally of the United States — spoke up to heap praise on his host: Vladimir Putin, the bête noire of the rules-based order.

title: Stephen Bannon, Released From Prison, Says He Is ‘Empowered’
description: Stephen K. Bannon, the combative and calculating strategist who helped elect Donald J. Trump to the White House and later used his influence as one of the most powerful voices of the hard right to sow baseless doubts about the 2020 election, was released from federal prison early Tuesday.

title: With Limited Options, Zelensky Seeks a Path Forward for Ukraine
description: For weeks, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has pushed Western leaders to support his so-called victory plan, which he claims will end the country’s war with Russia next year. But Mr. Zelensky has received only lukewarm rhetorical support.

title: ‘Standing Tall:’ Why ‘Perfect Strangers’ Keeps Coming Back
description: In the latest season of “Only Murders in the Building,” the show’s trio of amateur detectives are investigating yet another murder and discover a theme — and a song — from an unlikely source: another TV show.

title: Inside the Colorful and Cultish World of Nerds Gummy Clusters
description: How does a candy brand that was started 40 years ago suddenly become one of the most popular treats in America, with a cult following, a Super Bowl ad and TikTok fame?

title: Hezbollah Names Naim Qassem as Its New Leader
description: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group, named Naim Qassem, its longtime deputy leader, as its new secretary general on Tuesday, replacing Hassan Nasrallah, who was assassinated in Israeli airstrikes south of Beirut last month.

title: The Connections Companion No. 507
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,229
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Foreign Election Interference, and Volkswagen May Close Factories
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: On the Ballot: An Immigration System Most Americans Never Wanted
description: If Donald J. Trump wins next week’s election, it will be in large part because voters embraced his message that the U.S. immigration system is broken.

title: A Book that Explains the 2024 Campaign
description: If you want to understand this year’s election, a book published in 1970 turns out to be surprisingly useful. Both liberal and conservative analysts have recently cited its ideas, and the Harris and Trump campaigns have embraced its arguments in different ways.

title: McDonald’s Seeks to Resolve E. Coli Crisis and Return Focus to Value
description: McDonald’s is aiming to move past the E. coli outbreak that has sickened dozens of people in recent weeks, projecting the food safety scare will not affect its full-year finances.

title: Jeff Bezos, Jerome Powell, Serena Williams and More at the DealBook Summit
description: We are pleased to announce our lineup for the DealBook Summit, which will be held on Dec. 4 at Jazz at Lincoln Center in New York. Andrew will host a series of conversations with the biggest newsmakers in the world of business, politics and culture. We hope you can join us in person.

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: N.B.A. First, Formal Apology, Election
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: In 1930s Rwanda, a Black Savior Is Coming, and She Might Be a Woman
description: In Scholastique Mukasonga’s new novel, “Sister Deborah,” Black American evangelists arrive in 1930s Rwanda with good tidings: A “Black Savior” — perhaps a “Celestial Woman” — is coming to the village of Nyabikenke, and soon, to bring Black people a bountiful harvest and salvation. The chief bearer of this joyful message is the eponymous healer-prophet, a charismatic woman of mysterious origin and powers who can speak in tongues. Her powerful Black feminist vision earns her scores of women followers; this book is not only her tale, but also theirs. As they search, strive, wait and hope, they disrupt their own lives as well as longstanding systems of patriarchy and colonialism; and this remarkable, recursive book about the power of belief — like its heroines — finds new form again and again.

title: Who Won the Oscars of American Fashion
description: The 2024 Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, otherwise known as the Oscars of American fashion, were held in the Museum of Natural History, in the atrium under the great blue whale, but the coming election was the elephant in the room. How could it not be?

title: A Rural Missouri Town Fights Big Tech, and Itself
description: They had already planted yard signs, volunteered at the farmers’ market booth and signed each and every one of the petitions, so now the residents of Peculiar, Mo., took to the field outside their homes to pray.

title: BP Profit Falls, but It Still Sees ‘Potential to Grow’ in Oil and Gas
description: BP’s share price fell more than 3 percent on Tuesday after the energy giant reported its lowest quarterly earnings in almost four years and suggested it might change its generous share buyback policy.

title: Vatican Issues First Report on Sexual Abuse, to Immediate Criticism
description: Ten years after it was established, a Vatican commission on clerical sexual abuse issued its first report on Tuesday, a limited step in self-accounting by some bishops that was immediately criticized by victims advocates as toothless and lacking independent verification.

title: Where’s Ivanka?
description: Ivanka Trump has been surfing. She’s posed in front of the Eiffel Tower, and attended a Formula 1 party in Miami in a race-car red dress. She took a dip with her children in a hot tub, hung out with Kim Kardashian in Malibu, and smiled alongside her husband, Jared Kushner, at the Acropolis.

title: Trump’s Environmental Claims Ignore Decades of Climate Science
description: In the final throes of the presidential campaign, Donald Trump is trying to cast himself as a protector of mother nature, even as he calls climate change a hoax.

title: In Closing, Harris Casts Herself as the Unifier and Trump as a ‘Petty Tyrant’
description: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

title: The World’s Doomsday Plant Vault Gets Thousands of New Seeds
description: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, in the far reaches of northern Norway, is meant to be humanity’s last resort. Imagine it as the world’s doomsday garden shed: a secure genetic capsule, kept safe in case some catastrophe — a meteor strike or climate disaster, perhaps — threatens the planet’s crops.

title: Dozens Are Killed in an Israeli Strike in North Gaza, Local Authorities say
description: Gaza’s health ministry said that at least 25 children were among those killed in an Israeli strike on a residential building in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza. The Israeli military said it was looking into the strike.

title: A New Insult Reminds Puerto Ricans of How Trump Treated Them
description: Carmen Yulín Cruz’s cellphone started buzzing on Sunday while she was at the airport in Connecticut, waiting for a flight to Puerto Rico. A standup comic at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally in New York had called Puerto Rico a “floating island of garbage.”

title: The Threats to The Presidential Election, Explained
description: Nick Corasaniti, a New York Times reporter covering voting, describes how the 2024 election could be complicated by litigation, disinformation and battles over certifying the vote.

title: Could the Vote Be Contested Again? 5 Threats to a Smooth Election.
description: For the past four years, Donald J. Trump has been proclaiming the American electoral process “rigged,” decrying events that displease him as “election interference” and laying the groundwork to contest another loss at the polls.

title: This Toad Is So Tiny That They Call It a Flea
description: At 6.95 tiny millimeters in length, this creature could fit on your fingertip. It is smaller than several ant species. While it sounds like a cricket, it’s not an insect: It’s an extremely small frog.

title: ‘Ragtime’ Crushed Brandon Uranowitz’s Dream. Now It’s Healing His Wounds.
description: In 1997, Brandon Uranowitz was a 10-year-old from West Orange, N.J., who dreamed of being on Broadway. He got one small foot in the door that year when he replaced Paul Dano as the wide-eyed little boy Edgar in the musical “Ragtime” during its premiere in Toronto.

title: Autumn in New York Has Been One of the City’s Driest Ever
description: On Saturday, Sarah Antebi, a 19-year-old sophomore at Barnard and Columbia, paused for a moment while running through Central Park to take in the fall foliage at the lake. It’s unusually resplendent for this time of year, with many of the trees just starting to turn orange and yellow.

title: Gnocchi’s Crispy — Let’s Eat
description: Hello! Ali here, filling in for Emily Weinstein this week.

title: ‘Hatred and Vitriol’ at the Trump Rally in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Dozens Killed in Israeli Strikes in Eastern Lebanon, Lebanese Officials Say
description: Israeli airstrikes on Monday killed at least 60 people in the Bekaa Valley, in eastern Lebanon, Lebanese officials said, in what appeared to be the deadliest barrage of strikes in the area since the conflict between Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah escalated last month.

title: A ‘Crime and Punishment’ Ballet? It’s Not as ‘Ludicrous’ as It Seems.
description: To make a narrative ballet based on “Crime and Punishment” might seem, in the words of the director James Bonas, “sort of ludicrous.”

title: Help! Budget Charged Us $450 to Clean Our Rental Car. Can They Do That?
description: We rented a car from the Budget agency at Kennedy Airport in New York this past August for a two-week family vacation. When we returned it, the staff member who checked it in told me everything was fine. But four days later Budget sent a letter saying it was charging my credit card $450 for “Excessive Interior Dirt — Sand.” I complained multiple times via email, sending them time-stamped photos and video I had taken of the car’s interior, to no avail. Can you help? Arden, Kells, Ireland

title: Ford Took an Early Lead in Electric Vehicles. Now G.M. Is Surging.
description: In the race to be second to Tesla in the U.S. electric vehicle market, Ford Motor leaped to an early lead four years ago over its crosstown rival, General Motors, with the Mustang Mach E, an electric sport utility vehicle with a design and a name that nodded to its classic sports car.

title: How Elon Musk Might Use His Pull With Trump to Help Tesla
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has promised, if he is re-elected, to do away with Biden administration policies that encourage the use and production of electric cars. Yet one of his biggest supporters is Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, which makes nearly half the electric vehicles sold in the United States.

title: C.D.C. Warns of Unusual Rise in Walking Pneumonia Cases
description: Infections with the bacteria that causes walking pneumonia have risen significantly this year, particularly among young children, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned this month.

title: Putin Flexes Nuclear Capabilities at Delicate Moment for Ukraine
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia presided over a nuclear training exercise on Tuesday that included practice launches of ballistic missiles, a move widely seen as an attempt to show force amid the ongoing war in Ukraine.

title: Urban Hell, a Place to Find God or Just Another New York City Street?
description: The photograph is of three fast-food chain restaurants as glimpsed from a pedestrian overpass at night.

title: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Endorsing presidential candidates
description: The Times editorial board first endorsed a presidential candidate in 1860 (our pick then was Abraham Lincoln). In every presidential race since then, the board has weighed in. This year we endorsed Kamala Harris for president.

title: New Vehicles, Face Paint and a 1,200-Foot Fall: The U.S. Army Prepares for War With China
description: Early one morning this month, 864 Army paratroopers bundled into C-17 transport planes at a base in Alaska and took off for a Great Power War exercise between three volcanic mountains on Hawaii’s Big Island.

title: A Celebrated Pianist’s Final Recording, Made With His Son
description: The pianist Maurizio Pollini was still exploring, right to the end.

title: Automatic Refunds for Significant Flight Disruptions: New Airline Rule Goes Into Effect
description: The Transportation Department’s new rule requiring airlines to provide prompt, automatic refunds to passengers enduring significant flight disruptions is now in effect.

title: What Happened When Chicago’s Mayor Followed a Teachers’ Union Playbook
description: For years, Chicago was ground zero for the Democratic Party’s big transition on education.

title: TSMC Chips Ended Up in Devices Made by China’s Huawei Despite U.S. Controls
description: The U.S. government has spent years weaving a web of controls to prevent Chinese companies from being able to buy or make cutting-edge computer chips.

title: CNN Bars Pro-Trump Guest After His ‘Beeper’ Remark to Mehdi Hasan
description: CNN barred a conservative commentator from its programs after he made on-air remarks on Monday that seemed to imply that another guest, the pundit Mehdi Hasan, was a member of Hezbollah.

title: Two Horror Authors on the Scary Books You Should Read
description: Halloween is just around the corner, so we turned to two great horror authors — Joe Hill (“The Fireman,” “NOS4A2”) and Stephen Graham Jones (“The Only Good Indians,” “My Heart Is a Chainsaw”) — for their recommendations of books to read this season.

title: In ‘Empty Beds,’ a Stark Reminder of War’s Youngest Victims
description: On a quiet block in Manhattan’s Little Ukraine in the East Village, passers-by are confronted with haunting reminders of war. A 100-foot-long mural shows children’s beds lined with stuffed animals and toys, but no children, symbolizing the thousands of Ukrainian children who were separated or taken from their families since Russia invaded their country in 2022.

title: Immense Deluge Floods Parts of Southern and Eastern Spain
description: The region of Andalusia received four times the amount of rain that usually falls in October in a single day.

title: In Botswana’s Election, Diamond Profits Are a Defining Issue
description: The Botswana Democratic Party, which has governed the southern African nation since its independence in 1966, enters Wednesday’s national elections facing an unlikely threat to its grip on power: diamonds.

title: Is There a Moral Choice for Catholic Voters?
description: In advice last month for Catholic voters in America, Pope Francis said that both Donald Trump and Kamala Harris “are against life, be it the one who kicks out migrants or be it the one who kills babies.” Following this, Francis urged voters to choose the “lesser evil,” though the moral math was up to the individual voter.

title: Teri Garr, Comic Actress in Offbeat Roles, Is Dead at 79
description: Teri Garr, the alternately shy and sassy blond actress whose little-girl voice, deadpan comic timing, expressive eyes and cinematic bravery in the face of seemingly crazy male characters made her a star of 1970s and ’80s movies and earned her an Oscar nomination for her role in “Tootsie,” died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 79.

title: 13 Scary Good Halloween Songs
description: Hello from your guest playlister for the day — I’m Dave Renard, an editor on the Culture desk who writes about music occasionally and tries to keep his record collection from outgrowing its allotted shelf space (currently failing).

title: Why Is Harris So Passionate About Abortion Rights? Her Past Work Holds Clues.
description: In April 2004, Kamala Harris was less than four months into her new job as San Francisco’s district attorney, a high-profile position that thrust her into the local headlines, when she flew to Washington, D.C., to become one face in a sea of more than a million.

title: A Month’s Worth of Rain Falls in a Single Day in Parts of Spain
description: Manuel Yerai, a farmer in southern Spain, watched helplessly on Monday night as hail the size of tennis balls ripped through the plastic sheeting covering his pepper plants, as Spain faced one of its most destructive rainfalls this year.

title: Despite Covid ‘Amnesia,’ the Pandemic Simmers Beneath the 2024 Race
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. walked onstage after a parade of pyrotechnics at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally outside Atlanta last week and immediately invoked a name that became a bugaboo of the right and a subject of wild conspiracy theories during the coronavirus pandemic: Bill Gates.

title: Regional Indian Flavors in the Flatiron District
description: At some of the newest Indian restaurants, regional fare is the focus. The same is true at Passerine. The chef Chetan Shetty is from Pune, near Mumbai, and he relies on spice blends his mother concocts and sends over. Chile-fueled kolhapuri ignites lamb tartare, ajwain masala adds pungency to baked oysters, and malwani spices dancing with vadouvan season fish. Greenmarket maitake mushrooms, sweet potatoes, collards, broccoli rabe and cabbage figure as well. There are surprising touches, too, like Comté and Hollandaise. The restaurant’s lounge, called the Drawing Room, has its own brief menu and leads to the well-upholstered dining room. The space was formerly occupied by Sona, which closed earlier this year. (Opens Friday)

title: Bad Bunny Responds to Racist Remarks at Trump Rally With a Message of Puerto Rican Pride
description: Bad Bunny, the Puerto Rican rapper, singer and international pop phenomenon, stepped up on Tuesday his condemnation of disparaging remarks about Puerto Rico that were made by a comedian at a rally for former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday.

title: Judge Refuses to Recuse Herself From Trump Assassination Case
description: Aileen M. Cannon, the federal judge overseeing the prosecution of a man accused of trying to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump, rejected the man’s request that she remove herself from the case, saying on Tuesday that she has no relationship with Mr. Trump even though he appointed her to the bench and she has ruled in his favor in a separate criminal matter.

title: Teri Garr Found the Soul in Memorable Ditsy Blondes
description: In “Tootsie,” Teri Garr perfected the polite way to say you had a bad time at a party. Bidding a friend good night, her character, a struggling actress named Sandy, tells him, “It was a wonderful party, my date left with someone else, I had a lot of fun, do you have any seconal?”

title: One Defendant Accepts a Plea Deal Amid Young Thug’s RICO Trial
description: A defendant in the racketeering and gang conspiracy case against the Atlanta rapper Young Thug and members of his YSL crew agreed to a plea deal in court on Tuesday.

title: Teen Accused in U.K. Dance Class Stabbing Is Charged With Terror Offenses
description: The teenager accused of fatally stabbing three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in England has been charged with additional offenses linked to terrorism, the police said on Tuesday.

title: How Trump Exploits Divisions Among Black and Latino Voters
description: In the Democratic imagination, “people of color” is a unifying term, a label for a durable coalition of Black and Latino voters, as well as Asian Americans, Arab Americans and Native Americans.

title: Musk’s PAC Hints at Vulgar Taunt Against Harris in Ad
description: The ad from Elon Musk’s PAC begins, “Kamala Harris is a C Word.”

title: Ahead of Harris’s Speech in Washington, Trump Tries to Focus on Immigration
description: Former President Donald J. Trump described immigration as the most important issue of the election in a speech on Tuesday that his aides cast as a closing argument hours ahead of Vice President Kamala Harris’s remarks at the Ellipse in Washington.

title: San Jose State Women’s Volleyball Team Finds Itself at Center of Transgender Debate
description: The San Jose State University women’s volleyball team is trying to make the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in 23 years. But first, it must find schools willing to play against it.

title: Trump Family Members and Biden Aides Among China Hack Targets
description: Members of former President Donald J. Trump’s family, as well as Biden administration and State Department officials, were among those targeted by the China-linked hackers who were able to break into telecommunications company systems, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Barbara Bush, Scion of Republican Royalty, Knocks on Doors for Kamala Harris
description: Barbara Bush, whose father and grandfather were the last two Republican presidents before Donald J. Trump, said she was backing his opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: What a ‘Tennessee Three’ Member Thinks She Can Achieve by Running for Senate
description: As Gloria Johnson, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Tennessee, has driven from diner to coffee shop to restaurant across the state, she has been met with a chorus of enthusiasm that a Democrat has shown up — and resignation that it most likely still won’t matter.

title: The Runza, a Favorite Nebraska Sandwich, Has a Cameo in the Campaign
description: It’s been a busy few months in Nebraska for the makers of what is most decidedly not a Hot Pocket.

title: Trump’s Extraordinarily Negative TV Ads
description: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are neck-and-neck in terms of how many television ads they’ve aired in battleground states. The tones of those ads, however, have been worlds apart from each other.

title: A New Celebrity Podcast Host Who Might Be a Surprise
description: Armie Hammer announced this week that he started a podcast.

title: Devices With ‘Free Gaza’ Messages Found at Ballot Box Fires
description: Investigators responding to arson fires at two ballot boxes in the Pacific Northwest this week found devices at both scenes marked with the words “Free Gaza,” according to two law enforcement officials.

title: Alphabet Revenue Jumps 15% to $88.3 Billion
description: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, reported strong revenue growth on Tuesday, as its business continued to excel despite tough regulatory scrutiny and growing competition.

title: 44 Million Voters Have Already Cast a Ballot. Most Voted Early in 2020, Too.
description: More than 44 million Americans have cast an early ballot so far this election cycle, a substantial total that cements how voting patterns have changed in the country since the 2020 election.

title: Man Who Attacked Paul Pelosi Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: David DePape, the intruder who broke into the home of Nancy Pelosi two years ago and bludgeoned her husband with a hammer, was sentenced on Tuesday to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: Trump Media Stock Jumps Again as Traders Bet on Election
description: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company are soaring on the expectation he will win next week’s presidential election.

title: Israel Hits Gaza Town for Third Time in Days, Killing Dozens, Officials Say
description: The Israeli military on Tuesday hit a town in the northern Gaza Strip for the third time in just over a week, striking a residential building and killing dozens of people, Gazan officials said, as Israel intensified its offensive in the territory after more than a year of war.

title: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Worrisome Business Deals
